passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Inside the nucleus of cells, our genes are arranged along twisted, double-stranded molecules of DNA called “chromosomes.” At the ends of these chromosomes are stretches of DNA called telomeres, which protect our genetic data, make it possible for cells to divide, and hold some secrets about the processes behind age and cancer; in addition, telomeres are made up of a series of repetitive nucleotide sequences that play an important role in protecting our chromosomes and can also have an impact on aging in cells.

(2). The word “telomere” originates from two Greek words: “telos” meaning end, and “meros” meaning part. The role of telomeres in protecting human DNA was first documented by scientists in the 1930s. One of the most prominent scientists of this era was Barbara McClintock, an American cytogeneticist (a scientist who studies the relationship between chromosomes and cell behavior). After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933, McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.

(3). Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions, which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body. In fact, deoxyribonucleic acid can be found in the nucleus of each living cell; therefore, chromosomes, and the DNA they contain, are passed down from parents to each future generation. In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.

(4). The number of individual cells in our bodies does not remain consistent throughout our lives since cells are continually reproducing through the process of copying themselves. This process is necessary to grow new skin, maintain our bones, produce more blood, and generally maintain the state of our bodies. In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.

(5). For the above reason, it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age rather than their chronological age. Over our lifetime, repeated copying means that telomeres gradually shorten, and thus become more ineffectual. Telomere shortening is a manifestation of the natural aging process, but telomere shortening can also be a result of lifestyle factors, such as stress, smoking, obesity, and poor diet and exercise habits.

(6). The link between telomere length and cellular aging has been well documented by the scientific community. In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. Important discoveries relating to the nature of telomeres and the inability of chromosomes to replicate their ends were made in the 1970s, though scientists at the time were yet to make the connection between telomere shortening and fixed number of cell divisions. It was only later that a private study by the biotechnology company, Geron, clearly showed the connection between telomere shortening and cellular aging.

(7). Since Geron’s discovery, several important scientific studies have been made in the field of telomere research. In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.

(8). Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres. More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women. It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.

(9). Furthermore, sufferers of the disease, dyskeratosis congenita experience an escalated rate of telomere shortening; documented effects of this disease not only include premature aging and death, but also increased incidence of severe infection, leukemia, intestinal disorder, cirrhosis (destructive scar tissue in the liver), and pulmonary fibrosis (a toughening of lung tissue, which can be fatal). Other symptoms of dyskeratosis congenita are impaired wound healing, bone softening, learning disabilities, as well as factors commonly associated with aging, such as balding or graying of the hair and skin spots. Scientists believe that the previously mentioned disorders, all of which involve tissues within cells that have a higher rate of reproduction, are a result of the presence of shortened telomeres.

(10). Extensive research has been done looking into the connection between telomeres and cancer. Increased cell reproduction is a common feature in many types of cancer; such a heightened rate of cell division results in an escalation of telomere shortening. This phenomenon has been especially observed in pancreatic, bone, prostate, bladder, lung, kidney, and head and neck cancers. In most instances, cells protect themselves by increasing telomerase production, thus keeping the telomeres from reducing. However, in extreme cases, such as escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.

(11). Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: Telomerase is an enzyme that speeds up the process of telomere shortening. Telomeres are found in the nucleus of all human cells. Telomeres are present within the nucleus of every human cell.

options.label: C.
options.text: The first statement is TRUE, the second is FALSE

options.label: D.
options.text: The first statement is FALSE, the second is TRUE

correct_answer_text: The first statement is FALSE, the second is TRUE

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first ascertain whether the first statement is true or false; the first statement makes a claim regarding what telomerase does – this is a basic piece of information about telomerase and can probably be found in the section of the passage where telomerase is first mentioned. If we scan the passage, it is initially discussed in the fourth paragraph. Paragraph 4 reads: “In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.” The first statement in the question reads, “ Telomerase is an enzyme that speeds up the process of telomere shortening,” but the above paragraph informs us that telomeres do not speed up the process of telomere shortening. Thus, the first statement in the question is false. To ascertain whether the second statement in the question is true or false, it should be noted that the second statement makes a claim regarding where telomeres are found – this is a basic piece of information about telomeres and can probably be found in the section of the passage where telomeres are first mentioned. Indeed, the first sentence of paragraph 1 tells us that chromosomes are found inside the nucleolus of all cells and that telomeres are found at the ends of these chromosomes. Therefore, telomeres are found in the nucleus of all human cells. This means that the second statement is true. It reads: “ Inside the nucleus of cells, our genes are arranged along twisted, double-stranded molecules of DNA called “chromosomes.” At the ends of these chromosomes are stretches of DNA called telomeres…” Thus, the first statement is FALSE, and the second statement is TRUE. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Both statements are TRUE – is incorrect because the first statement is false. In paragraph 4, the author says that shortening of telomeres is mitigated by telomerase, not worsened. Option B. Both statements are FALSE – is incorrect because the second statement is true. In paragraph 1, the author says that at the ends of chromosomes, there is a special DNA called telomeres and that this DNA is found in the nucleus. Option C. The first statement is TRUE, the second is FALSE – is incorrect because the opposite is true; the first statement is false, and the second is true. In paragraph 4, the author says that shortening of telomeres is mitigated by telomerase, which proves statement 1 incorrect. In paragraph 1, the author says that at the ends of chromosomes, there is a special DNA called telomeres and that this DNA is found in the nucleus, which proves statement 2 correct.

question.text: A critical function of telomeres in humans is their maintenance of a healthy body because they regulate and control cell reproduction.

options.label: A.
options.text: Both the statement and reason are correct and related

options.label: B.
options.text: Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related

options.label: C.
options.text: The statement is correct, but the reason is NOT

options.label: D.
options.text: The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct

options.label: E.
options.text: NEITHER the statement NOR the reason is correct

correct_answer_text: The statement is correct, but the reason is NOT

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first ascertain whether the statement given in the question is true or false; if we note that the title of the passage is “Telomeres,” it can be presumed that this is the main topic of the passage. Since the first statement in the question makes a claim about the role of telomeres and thus makes a claim related to a basic piece of information about telomeres, we can guess that the paragraph telling us whether the first statement is true or false will probably be found early in the passage. In paragraph 3, the author discusses telomeres and mentions the statement below. This tells us that telomeres do play an essential role in maintaining a healthy human body. Thus, the statement is correct. “In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.” We should now ascertain whether the reason given in the question is true or false; to do so, consider the fact that, as with the statement given in the question, the reason also pertains to the function of telomeres. As we have established above, paragraph 3 discusses the function of telomeres. Thus, we can presume that the information needed to establish whether the reason in the question is true or false can be found in or around the same section of the passage as paragraph 3. Indeed, the author mentions the statement below in paragraph 4. This does not imply that telomeres can regulate and control cell reproduction. This tells us that the reason is incorrect. “In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied… “ Thus, the statement is correct, but the reason is incorrect. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Both the statement and reason are correct and related – is incorrect because the reason is incorrect; the claim that telomeres regulate as well as control cell reproduction is not mentioned in the passage. Instead, in paragraph 4, the author states that telomeres merely become shorter with each cycle of cell reproduction. Option B. Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related – is incorrect because the reason is incorrect. Telomeres do not regulate and control cell reproduction. In paragraph 4, the author states that telomeres merely become shorter with each cycle of cell reproduction. Option D. The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct – is incorrect because the statement is correct, but the reason is incorrect. In paragraph three, the author states that telomeres play an essential role in maintaining a healthy body in humans; this proves the statement correct. The reason is disproved in paragraph 4 when the author states: “In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time.” This does not mean the same as telomeres regulating and controlling cell reproduction. Option E. NEITHER the statement NOR the reason is correct – is incorrect because the statement is correct, but the reason is not. In paragraph three, the author states that telomeres play an essential role in maintaining a healthy body in humans; this proves the statement correct. The reason is disproved in paragraph 4 when the author states: “In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time.” This does not mean the same as telomeres regulating and controlling cell reproduction.

question.text: Why are there concerns associated with treatments that involve hindering telomerase production?

options.label: A.
options.text: The chance of cellular necrosis is greater

options.label: B.
options.text: It puts individuals at risk for a variety of disorders

options.label: D.
options.text: Studies have linked a decrease in telomerase to increased tumor growth

options.label: E.
options.text: It impedes the production of telomeres in cells, the effects of which haven’t been studied

correct_answer_text: It puts individuals at risk for a variety of disorders

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, notice that it asks for information regarding treatments that hinder telomerase; now scan the passage for a paragraph or paragraphs discussing this topic. This type of treatment is discussed most in-depth in the eleventh paragraph of the passage. Paragraph 11 reads: “…others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die; however, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.” If we scan the list of risks associated with the halting of telomerase and then return to the answer choices given in the options, the only match is the second option choice to the final risk listed; this is because the increased risk for diseases would be an outcome of loss of immune cell production. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The chance of cellular necrosis is greater – is incorrect because, in paragraph 10, the author states: “One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die…” This does not mean the same as telomerase treatments increasing the odds of cell necrosis, and it is not listed as one of the risks for the treatment; thus, Option A is incorrect. Option C. It causes uncontrolled apoptosis – is incorrect because, in paragraph 10, the author states: “In extreme cases, such an escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.” This does not mean the same as telomerase treatments always causing apoptosis, and it is not listed as one of the risks for the treatment; thus, Option C is incorrect. Option D. Studies have connected lack of telomerase to the growth of tumours – is incorrect because there are no studies mentioned in the passage that link the absence of telomerase to the creation of tumors. Option E. It impedes the production of telomeres in cells, the effects of which haven’t been studied – is incorrect because this is a false statement; while the treatments mentioned do block telomerase production in cells, the effects have been studied. For instance, paragraph 4 states: “One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die…”

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Inside the nucleus of cells, our genes are arranged along twisted, double-stranded molecules of DNA called “chromosomes.” At the ends of these chromosomes are stretches of DNA called telomeres, which protect our genetic data, make it possible for cells to divide, and hold some secrets about the processes behind age and cancer; in addition, telomeres are made up of a series of repetitive nucleotide sequences that play an important role in protecting our chromosomes and can also have an impact on aging in cells.

(2). The word “telomere” originates from two Greek words: “telos” meaning end, and “meros” meaning part. The role of telomeres in protecting human DNA was first documented by scientists in the 1930s. One of the most prominent scientists of this era was Barbara McClintock, an American cytogeneticist (a scientist who studies the relationship between chromosomes and cell behavior). After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933, McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.

(3). Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions, which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body. In fact, deoxyribonucleic acid can be found in the nucleus of each living cell; therefore, chromosomes, and the DNA they contain, are passed down from parents to each future generation. In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.

(4). The number of individual cells in our bodies does not remain consistent throughout our lives since cells are continually reproducing through the process of copying themselves. This process is necessary to grow new skin, maintain our bones, produce more blood, and generally maintain the state of our bodies. In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.

(5). For the above reason, it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age rather than their chronological age. Over our lifetime, repeated copying means that telomeres gradually shorten, and thus become more ineffectual. Telomere shortening is a manifestation of the natural aging process, but telomere shortening can also be a result of lifestyle factors, such as stress, smoking, obesity, and poor diet and exercise habits.

(6). The link between telomere length and cellular aging has been well documented by the scientific community. In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. Important discoveries relating to the nature of telomeres and the inability of chromosomes to replicate their ends were made in the 1970s, though scientists at the time were yet to make the connection between telomere shortening and fixed number of cell divisions. It was only later that a private study by the biotechnology company, Geron, clearly showed the connection between telomere shortening and cellular aging.

(7). Since Geron’s discovery, several important scientific studies have been made in the field of telomere research. In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.

(8). Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres. More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women. It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.

(9). Furthermore, sufferers of the disease, dyskeratosis congenita experience an escalated rate of telomere shortening; documented effects of this disease not only include premature aging and death, but also increased incidence of severe infection, leukemia, intestinal disorder, cirrhosis (destructive scar tissue in the liver), and pulmonary fibrosis (a toughening of lung tissue, which can be fatal). Other symptoms of dyskeratosis congenita are impaired wound healing, bone softening, learning disabilities, as well as factors commonly associated with aging, such as balding or graying of the hair and skin spots. Scientists believe that the previously mentioned disorders, all of which involve tissues within cells that have a higher rate of reproduction, are a result of the presence of shortened telomeres.

(10). Extensive research has been done looking into the connection between telomeres and cancer. Increased cell reproduction is a common feature in many types of cancer; such a heightened rate of cell division results in an escalation of telomere shortening. This phenomenon has been especially observed in pancreatic, bone, prostate, bladder, lung, kidney, and head and neck cancers. In most instances, cells protect themselves by increasing telomerase production, thus keeping the telomeres from reducing. However, in extreme cases, such as escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.

(11). Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: Each of the following are mentioned as a potential effect of the absence of telomeres EXCEPT one. Which is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: C.
options.text: The speed at which cells divide could be hindered

options.label: D.
options.text: The instructions informing cells how to act could be disrupted

correct_answer_text: The speed at which cells divide could be hindered

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the title of the passage is “Telomeres.” It can be presumed that this is the main topic of the passage; since the question at hand asks about the effects of telomere’s absence and thus asks a question related to a basic piece of information about telomeres, we can guess that the paragraph telling us about the effects of telomere’s absence will be found early in the passage. Indeed, in paragraph 3, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that the effects of absent telomeres are chromosomes becoming damaged or merging together, damage to cell behavior instructions, and cell death. “Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation ; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions , which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body.” We should now scan the answer choices we have been given for an option NOT listed in paragraph 3. The only answer choice NOT listed is an interruption to the rate of cell division. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. There is potential for harm to the chromosomes – is incorrect because this is mentioned in paragraph 3 as being one of the potential effects of the absence of telomeres. Thus, the author does mention that chromosomes can be damaged. Option B. Chromosomes may merge as one – is incorrect because this is mentioned in paragraph 3 as being one of the potential effects of the absence of telomeres. Thus, the author does mention that chromosomes can fuse. Option D. The speed at which cells divide could be hindered – is incorrect because this is mentioned in paragraph 3 as being one of the potential effects of the absence of telomeres. Thus, the author does mention that DNA, which instructs cell behavior, could be damaged. Option E. Cell destruction could occur – is incorrect because this is mentioned in paragraph 3 as being one of the potential effects of the absence of telomeres. Thus, the author does mention that cell degradation can occur.

question.text: How many Nobel prize winners in medicine or physiology does the author reference in the passage?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, scan the passage for mention of the phrase “Nobel Prize,” then check each sentence containing this phrase for the names of the prize’s winners; having done so, simply add up the number of winners mentioned in the passage. Nobel Prize winners are mentioned in paragraphs two, seven, and fourteen. Paragraph 2 reads: “Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.” Paragraph 7 reads: “In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.” Paragraph 14 reads: “Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed.” Together, McClintock, the three scientists, and Blackburn equal five Nobel Prize winners mentioned in the passage. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 2 – is incorrect because the author mentions more than two Nobel Prize-winning scientists in the passage. The first instance is in paragraph 2, the second in paragraph 7, and the last in paragraph 14. Option B. 3 – is incorrect because the author mentions more than three Nobel Prize-winning scientists in the passage. The first instance is in paragraph 2, the second in paragraph 7, and the last in paragraph 14. Option C. 4 – is incorrect because the author mentions more than four Nobel Prize-winning scientists in the passage. The first instance is in paragraph 2, the second in paragraph 7, and the last in paragraph 14. Option E. 6 – is incorrect because the author only mentions five Nobel Prize-winning scientists in the passage, not 6. The first instance is in paragraph 2, the second in paragraph 7, and the last in paragraph 14.

question.text: What statement most accurately reflects the main idea of paragraph 8?

options.label: A.
options.text: Men and the elderly are at higher risk of accelerated aging

options.label: B.
options.text: The risk of contracting an infectious disease is increased with shortened telomeres

options.label: C.
options.text: Shortened telomeres can have extreme health effects, with men being more susceptible

options.label: D.
options.text: To increase telomere length, individuals must assess their health and consult an expert

options.label: E.
options.text: Telomere shortening is the leading cause of most immune diseases

correct_answer_text: Shortened telomeres can have extreme health effects, with men being more susceptible

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should read the paragraph in question (paragraph 8) carefully. Having done so, we should then divide the paragraph into its main points and select an answer choice that encompasses said points. Part 1 of paragraph 8 tells us that shortened telomeres can cause negative health effects. It reads: “Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease…” Part 2 tells us that the negative health effects of shortened telomeres can be extreme. It reads: “More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women.” Part 3 tells us that men may be at a higher risk for shortened telomeres compared to women. It reads: “It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.” We should now summarize the sections of paragraph 8 that we have divided above; by doing so, we can determine its main idea. Summarizing the divided sections of paragraph 8, we can say that shortened telomeres have the potential to cause extremely negative health effects and that men are at higher risk for shortened telomeres than women. Only the third answer choice in the options matches this summary in its entirety. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Men and the elderly are at higher risk of accelerated aging – is incorrect because this is a false statement. Paragraph 8 only mentions that “individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease, and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease, compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres.” Paragraph 8 does not imply that those with shortened telomeres are at a higher risk for accelerated aging, and thus Option A is incorrect. Additionally, Option A is not representative of the entirety of paragraph 8. Option B. The risk of contacting an infectious disease is increased with shortened telomeres – is incorrect because this is an incorrect statement. Paragraph 8 states: “A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease, and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease, compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres.” Increased likelihood of dying from an infectious disease is not the same as increased likelihood of contracting an infectious disease; it only means that an affected individual is more likely to die from said disease. Thus, Option B is incorrect. Additionally, Option B is not representative of the entirety of paragraph 8. Option D. To increase telomere length, individuals must assess their health and consult an expert – is incorrect because the idea of consulting a clinician to increase telomere length is not mentioned in paragraph 8; therefore, it cannot be the main idea. Option E. Telomere shortening is the leading cause of most immune diseases – is incorrect because this is a false statement. Telomere shortening as the leading cause of most immune diseases is not mentioned in paragraph 8 and therefore cannot be its main idea.

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Inside the nucleus of cells, our genes are arranged along twisted, double-stranded molecules of DNA called “chromosomes.” At the ends of these chromosomes are stretches of DNA called telomeres, which protect our genetic data, make it possible for cells to divide, and hold some secrets about the processes behind age and cancer; in addition, telomeres are made up of a series of repetitive nucleotide sequences that play an important role in protecting our chromosomes and can also have an impact on aging in cells.

(2). The word “telomere” originates from two Greek words: “telos” meaning end, and “meros” meaning part. The role of telomeres in protecting human DNA was first documented by scientists in the 1930s. One of the most prominent scientists of this era was Barbara McClintock, an American cytogeneticist (a scientist who studies the relationship between chromosomes and cell behavior). After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933, McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.

(3). Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions, which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body. In fact, deoxyribonucleic acid can be found in the nucleus of each living cell; therefore, chromosomes, and the DNA they contain, are passed down from parents to each future generation. In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.

(4). The number of individual cells in our bodies does not remain consistent throughout our lives since cells are continually reproducing through the process of copying themselves. This process is necessary to grow new skin, maintain our bones, produce more blood, and generally maintain the state of our bodies. In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.

(5). For the above reason, it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age rather than their chronological age. Over our lifetime, repeated copying means that telomeres gradually shorten, and thus become more ineffectual. Telomere shortening is a manifestation of the natural aging process, but telomere shortening can also be a result of lifestyle factors, such as stress, smoking, obesity, and poor diet and exercise habits.

(6). The link between telomere length and cellular aging has been well documented by the scientific community. In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. Important discoveries relating to the nature of telomeres and the inability of chromosomes to replicate their ends were made in the 1970s, though scientists at the time were yet to make the connection between telomere shortening and fixed number of cell divisions. It was only later that a private study by the biotechnology company, Geron, clearly showed the connection between telomere shortening and cellular aging.

(7). Since Geron’s discovery, several important scientific studies have been made in the field of telomere research. In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.

(8). Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres. More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women. It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.

(9). Furthermore, sufferers of the disease, dyskeratosis congenita experience an escalated rate of telomere shortening; documented effects of this disease not only include premature aging and death, but also increased incidence of severe infection, leukemia, intestinal disorder, cirrhosis (destructive scar tissue in the liver), and pulmonary fibrosis (a toughening of lung tissue, which can be fatal). Other symptoms of dyskeratosis congenita are impaired wound healing, bone softening, learning disabilities, as well as factors commonly associated with aging, such as balding or graying of the hair and skin spots. Scientists believe that the previously mentioned disorders, all of which involve tissues within cells that have a higher rate of reproduction, are a result of the presence of shortened telomeres.

(10). Extensive research has been done looking into the connection between telomeres and cancer. Increased cell reproduction is a common feature in many types of cancer; such a heightened rate of cell division results in an escalation of telomere shortening. This phenomenon has been especially observed in pancreatic, bone, prostate, bladder, lung, kidney, and head and neck cancers. In most instances, cells protect themselves by increasing telomerase production, thus keeping the telomeres from reducing. However, in extreme cases, such as escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.

(11). Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: What are the meanings of the two Greek words from which the word "telomere" has its origin?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, consider the fact that the passage is titled “Telomeres.” This tells us that the meaning of the word “telomere” will likely be found early in the passage. Paragraph 2 reads: “The word “telomere” originates from two Greek words: “telos” meaning end , and “meros” meaning part .” Thus, “telomere” has its origins in the Greek words for “part” and “end.” Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.

Additionally, in paragraph 2, the author states that the word “telomere” originates from “telos” and “meros” which mean “end” and “part” in English. Option B. “Gene” and “end” – is incorrect because the author does not provide a Greek translation of the English word “gene” in the passage. Additionally, in paragraph 2, the author states that the word “telomere” originates from “telos” and “meros” which mean “end” and “part” in English. Option D. “Part” and “tip’ ”– is incorrect because the author does not provide a Greek translation of the English word “tip” in the passage. Additionally, in paragraph 2, the author states that the word “telomere” originates from “telos” and “meros” which mean “end” and “part” in English. Option E. “End” and “tip” – is incorrect because the author does not provide a Greek translation of the English word “tip” in the passage. Additionally, in paragraph 2, the author states that the word “telomere” originates from “telos” and “meros” which mean “end” and “part” in English.

question.text: What determines the “biological age” of a cell?

options.label: A.
options.text: The amount of time that the cell has existed

options.label: B.
options.text: The number of times the cell has divided

options.label: C.
options.text: It is determined by genetic factors

options.label: D.
options.text: The chronological age of the cell

options.label: E.
options.text: The length of the cell's RNA

correct_answer_text: The number of times the cell has divided

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, consider the theme of the passage in its entirety. If we consider that the passage focuses mainly on telomeres, and that telomeres are inside cells, then we can conclude that information such as what determines the biological age of a cell will probably be found early in the passage, as such information could be said to constitute basic knowledge about telomeres. Indeed, the information required to answer the question at hand can be found in the fourth and fifth paragraphs of the passage. These paragraphs tell us that telomere length is determined by the number of times cells have divided, which in turn defines a cell’s biological age. Paragraph 4 states: “…after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.” Paragraph 5 states: “ …it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age, rather than their chronological age.” Thus, a cell’s biological age is determined by the number of times it has divided. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The amount of time that the cell has existed – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, the author of the passage states in paragraph 5: “…it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age, rather than their chronological age.” Option C. It is determined by genetic factors – is incorrect because the author of the passage states in paragraph 5: “…it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age, rather than their chronological age.” Option D. The chronological age of the cell – is incorrect because the author of the passage states in paragraph 5: “…it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age, rather than their chronological age.” Option E. The length of the cell’s RNA – is incorrect because the author of the passage states in paragraph 5: “…it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age, rather than their chronological age.”

question.text: Which of the following would the author most likely agree to be the event that first linked telomere shortening to aging?

options.label: A.
options.text: The private study conducted by Geron

options.label: B.
options.text: The study undertaken at Utah University

options.label: C.
options.text: The revolutionary work of Barbara McClintock

options.label: E.
options.text: The revelation of the link between dyskeratosis congenita and telomere shortening

correct_answer_text: The private study conducted by Geron

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should refer to the passage and consider which event revealed the connection between telomeres and aging; by looking closely at the passage, we can see that this event is discussed in the sixth paragraph. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.

The revolutionary work of Barbara McClintock – is incorrect because, while McClintock was mentioned in the passage, the passage states that “she determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes.” McClintock did not link telomere shortening to aging. (1). Inside the nucleus of cells, our genes are arranged along twisted, double-stranded molecules of DNA called “chromosomes.” At the ends of these chromosomes are stretches of DNA called telomeres, which protect our genetic data, make it possible for cells to divide, and hold some secrets about the processes behind age and cancer; in addition, telomeres are made up of a series of repetitive nucleotide sequences that play an important role in protecting our chromosomes and can also have an impact on aging in cells.

(2). The word “telomere” originates from two Greek words: “telos” meaning end, and “meros” meaning part. The role of telomeres in protecting human DNA was first documented by scientists in the 1930s. One of the most prominent scientists of this era was Barbara McClintock, an American cytogeneticist (a scientist who studies the relationship between chromosomes and cell behavior). After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933, McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.

(3). Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions, which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body. In fact, deoxyribonucleic acid can be found in the nucleus of each living cell; therefore, chromosomes, and the DNA they contain, are passed down from parents to each future generation. In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.

(4). The number of individual cells in our bodies does not remain consistent throughout our lives since cells are continually reproducing through the process of copying themselves. This process is necessary to grow new skin, maintain our bones, produce more blood, and generally maintain the state of our bodies. In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.

(5). For the above reason, it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age rather than their chronological age. Over our lifetime, repeated copying means that telomeres gradually shorten, and thus become more ineffectual. Telomere shortening is a manifestation of the natural aging process, but telomere shortening can also be a result of lifestyle factors, such as stress, smoking, obesity, and poor diet and exercise habits.

(6). The link between telomere length and cellular aging has been well documented by the scientific community. In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. Important discoveries relating to the nature of telomeres and the inability of chromosomes to replicate their ends were made in the 1970s, though scientists at the time were yet to make the connection between telomere shortening and fixed number of cell divisions. It was only later that a private study by the biotechnology company, Geron, clearly showed the connection between telomere shortening and cellular aging.

(7). Since Geron’s discovery, several important scientific studies have been made in the field of telomere research. In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.

(8). Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres. More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women. It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.

(9). Furthermore, sufferers of the disease, dyskeratosis congenita experience an escalated rate of telomere shortening; documented effects of this disease not only include premature aging and death, but also increased incidence of severe infection, leukemia, intestinal disorder, cirrhosis (destructive scar tissue in the liver), and pulmonary fibrosis (a toughening of lung tissue, which can be fatal). Other symptoms of dyskeratosis congenita are impaired wound healing, bone softening, learning disabilities, as well as factors commonly associated with aging, such as balding or graying of the hair and skin spots. Scientists believe that the previously mentioned disorders, all of which involve tissues within cells that have a higher rate of reproduction, are a result of the presence of shortened telomeres.

(10). Extensive research has been done looking into the connection between telomeres and cancer. Increased cell reproduction is a common feature in many types of cancer; such a heightened rate of cell division results in an escalation of telomere shortening. This phenomenon has been especially observed in pancreatic, bone, prostate, bladder, lung, kidney, and head and neck cancers. In most instances, cells protect themselves by increasing telomerase production, thus keeping the telomeres from reducing. However, in extreme cases, such as escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.

(11). Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: Which of the following offers the most accurate description of telomerase reverse transcriptase?

options.label: A.
options.text: An enzyme that reduces the shortening of telomeres

options.label: C.
options.text: The molecule which provides structural integrity to telomeres

options.label: D.
options.text: A substance that facilitates the process in which telomeres multiply

options.label: E.
options.text: A substance that decreases the efficiency of telomeres

correct_answer_text: An enzyme that reduces the shortening of telomeres

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, scan the passage for the phrase “telomerase reverse transcriptase.” This phrase is found only once, in the fourth paragraph. Thus, it can be presumed that a description of telomerase reverse transcriptase will be found in this paragraph. Paragraph 4 reads: “In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase . However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.” This tells us that telomerase reverse transcriptase is an enzyme that reduces the shortening of telomeres. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. An enzyme that lengthens telomeres – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, telomerase reverse transcriptase more specifically mitigates the shortening of telomeres in each cycle of cell reproduction - it doesn’t merely lengthen telomeres. Option C. The molecule which provides structural integrity to telomeres – is incorrect because telomerase reverse transcriptase mitigates the shortening of telomeres in each cycle of cell reproduction; this does not relate to structural integrity. Option D. A substance that facilitates the process in which telomeres multiply – is incorrect because telomerase reverse transcriptase mitigates the shortening of telomeres in each cycle of cell reproduction; this does not facilitate a process that allows telomeres to multiply. Option E. A substance that decreases the efficiency of telomeres – is incorrect because this is a false statement. Telomerase reverse transcriptase mitigates the shortening of telomeres in each cycle of cell reproduction, which increases the efficacy of telomeres; it does not decrease their efficacy.

question.text: In which of the below journals would the topic discussed within this passage most likely be published?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, consider which of the journals listed aligns most closely with the overall topic of the passage, aging and telomeres; now consider the branch of science a discussion of aging and telomeres would most likely fall under. Since molecular biology is a branch of science that studies cellular activity, and telomeres are in the cells of the body, we can conclude that the topic discussed within this passage (aging and telomeres) would most likely be discussed in a journal of molecular biology . Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. American Journal of Clinical Nutrition – is incorrect because, although telomere shortening is associated with a poor diet, this is not the best answer as it does not encompass the overall topic of the passage. Option C. New England Journal of Medicine – is incorrect because this journal is concerned with medicine, whereas the article discusses at length the link between aging and telomeres. Option D. Applied and Environmental Microbiology – is incorrect because microbiology is not linked to the subject of the passage, which is telomeres. Option E. Journal of Gerontology – is incorrect because the passage discusses at length the link between aging and telomeres.

question.text: In what year was a study published demonstrating the crucial link between telomere shortening and aging?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, scan the passage for mentions of dates, then check the paragraphs containing these dates for important events that happened on or around said times. Paragraph 2 mentions the 1930s (1933 specifically), paragraph 6 mentions the 1970s, and paragraph 7 mentions 2009, as well as “the following year.” In paragraph 7, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that the link between telomerase and telomere shortening was discovered in 2009, but that one year later, in 2010 , the link between telomere shortening and aging in cells was discovered. “In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.” Thus, the study demonstrating the key link between telomere shortening and cellular aging was released in 2010. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 1930 – is incorrect because this date is mentioned in paragraph 2: “The role of telomeres in protecting human DNA was first documented by scientists in the 1930s.” This documentation did not record the link between telomere shortening and cellular aging. Option B. 1933 – is incorrect because this date is mentioned in paragraph 2: “After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933 McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.” McClintock did not demonstrate the link between telomere shortening and cellular aging. Option C. 1970 – is incorrect because this date is mentioned in paragraph 6: “In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. Important discoveries relating to the nature of telomeres and the inability of chromosomes to replicate their ends were made in the 1970s…” The discoveries made in the 1970s did not find the link between telomere shortening and cellular aging. Option D. 2009 – is incorrect because while this may seem correct, the paragraph states: “In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.” These scientists did not demonstrate the link between telomere shortening and cellular aging, which was done by Harvard Medical School the following year in 2010!
