(7). Since Geron’s discovery, several important scientific studies have been made in the field of telomere research. In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.

(8). Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres. More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women. It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.

(9). Furthermore, sufferers of the disease, dyskeratosis congenita experience an escalated rate of telomere shortening; documented effects of this disease not only include premature aging and death, but also increased incidence of severe infection, leukemia, intestinal disorder, cirrhosis (destructive scar tissue in the liver), and pulmonary fibrosis (a toughening of lung tissue, which can be fatal). Other symptoms of dyskeratosis congenita are impaired wound healing, bone softening, learning disabilities, as well as factors commonly associated with aging, such as balding or graying of the hair and skin spots. Scientists believe that the previously mentioned disorders, all of which involve tissues within cells that have a higher rate of reproduction, are a result of the presence of shortened telomeres.

(10). Extensive research has been done looking into the connection between telomeres and cancer. Increased cell reproduction is a common feature in many types of cancer; such a heightened rate of cell division results in an escalation of telomere shortening. This phenomenon has been especially observed in pancreatic, bone, prostate, bladder, lung, kidney, and head and neck cancers. In most instances, cells protect themselves by increasing telomerase production, thus keeping the telomeres from reducing. However, in extreme cases, such as escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.

(11). Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: According to research from the University of Utah, how much more at risk are individuals with shorter telomeres of contracting contagious diseases compared to those with longer telomeres?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage for the paragraph or paragraphs mentioning studies undertaken by the University of Utah. This university is only mentioned in paragraph 8, which reads: “Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from the infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres.” This tells us that people with shortened telomeres are eight times more likely to succumb to infectious disease compared to those with longer telomeres. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Three times – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states that individuals with shortened telomeres were three times more likely to die of heart disease than those with longer telomeres, not infectious disease: “A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease…” Option C. Two times – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states that individuals with shortened telomeres are eight times more likely to succumb to infectious disease than those with longer telomeres, not two times: “A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease, and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease, compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres.” Option D. Five times – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states that individuals with shortened telomeres are eight times more likely to succumb to infectious disease than those with longer telomeres, not five times: “A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease, and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease, compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres.”

One of the most prominent scientists of this era was Barbara McClintock, an American cytogeneticist (a scientist who studies the relationship between chromosomes and cell behavior). After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933, McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.

(3). Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions, which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body. In fact, deoxyribonucleic acid can be found in the nucleus of each living cell; therefore, chromosomes, and the DNA they contain, are passed down from parents to each future generation. In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.

(4). The number of individual cells in our bodies does not remain consistent throughout our lives since cells are continually reproducing through the process of copying themselves. This process is necessary to grow new skin, maintain our bones, produce more blood, and generally maintain the state of our bodies. In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.

(5). For the above reason, it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age rather than their chronological age. Over our lifetime, repeated copying means that telomeres gradually shorten, and thus become more ineffectual. (6). The link between telomere length and cellular aging has been well documented by the scientific community. In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. question.text: Some scientists believe cancer treatments could be developed by blocking telomerase production, causing cancer cells to die.

options.label: A.
options.text: Both the statement and reason are correct and related

options.label: B.
options.text: Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related

options.label: C.
options.text: The statement is correct but the reason is NOT

options.label: D.
options.text: The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct

options.label: E.
options.text: NEITHER the statement NOR the reason is correct

correct_answer_text: Both the statement and reason are correct and related

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the statement and the reason are based on the same topic (a type of potential cancer treatment). Thus, it is likely that the information required to ascertain the truth or falsity of the statement and the reason given in the question will be found in the same section of the passage. To find this information, we should search the passage for a paragraph discussing cancer treatments. Although cancer is mentioned several times throughout the passage, cancer treatment is discussed most in-depth in the eleventh paragraph. In paragraph 11, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that some scientists believe that a potential type of cancer treatment COULD involve blocking telomerase production, which would kill cancer cells. “…others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells.” Thus, both the statement and reason are correct and related. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Both the statement and the reason are correct but NOT related – is incorrect because the statement and reason are related. In paragraph 11, the author states that scientists believe blocking telomerase production could be a form of potential cancer treatment because blocking telomerase can cause cancer cells to die. These two ideas are related, which makes this option choice incorrect. Option C. The statement is correct, but the reason is NOT – is incorrect because the reason is also correct. The reasoning for the scientists’ belief is that the treatments would kill cancer cells, a fact that is confirmed in paragraph 11. Option D. The statement is NOT correct, but the reason is correct – is incorrect because the statement is also correct. In paragraph 11, the author states that scientists believe blocking telomerase production is a potential treatment for cancer. Option E. NEITHER the statement NOR the reason is correct – is incorrect because both the statement and the reason are correct. In paragraph 11, the author says that scientists believe that blocking telomerase production is a potential treatment for cancer. The reasoning for this is that the treatments would kill cancer cells.

question.text: Which of the following words most accurately reflects the author's tone in the passage?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, consider the passage in its entirety and reflect on what the author’s intention might have been for writing the piece. We can say that the author is attempting to inform the reader about telomeres by using facts and information and giving a broad overview of the subject of telomeres. As a result, the author’s intention seems to be to provide information about telomeres. Thus, the most accurate description of the author’s tone would be informative . Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Technical – is incorrect because “technical” means using a lot of specialist terminologies and including many small details, as opposed to giving a broader overview of a subject. This is not the best way to describe the author’s tone; thus, “technical” is incorrect. Option B. Illustrative – is incorrect because “illustrative” means using a lot of imagery and details that allow the reader to glean more about a given subject. This is not the best way to describe the author’s tone; thus, “illustrative” is incorrect. Option C. Casual – is incorrect because “casual” means using informal language and providing fewer facts. This is not the best way to describe the author’s tone; thus, “casual” is incorrect. Option E. Aggressive – is incorrect because “aggressive” means using very violent or hostile language. This is not the best way to describe the author’s tone; thus, “aggressive” is incorrect.

Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: Should scientists develop the technology, what is one possible outcome of the temporary activation of telomerase?

options.label: B.
options.text: The treatment of many different illnesses

options.label: C.
options.text: More rapid healing of injury sites

options.label: D.
options.text: A deceleration in the cellular aging process

correct_answer_text: A deceleration in the cellular aging process

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the stem uses the phrase “should scientists develop the technology.” This tells us that the science mentioned next (temporary activation of telomerase) has not yet been developed. Therefore, we should search the passage for the section that discusses future developments in the field of telomeres. Logically, it can be presumed that this section will be found at or close to the end of the text. Paragraphs 11–15 discuss future advances in telomeres, but paragraph 12 specifically discusses the temporary activation of telomerase. It reads: “Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells.” This tells us that temporary activation of telomerase could potentially slow or decelerate the aging process in cells. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The demise of cancer cells – is incorrect because paragraph 11 states that this is a potential outcome of halting telomerase production, not activating telomerase: “One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die.” Option B. The treatment of many different illnesses – is incorrect because paragraph fifteen states that this is a potential outcome of using telomerase to mass-produce cells: “A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases.” Option C. More rapid healing of injury sites – is incorrect because the healing of wounds is only mentioned in paragraph 9 as something impaired because of the disorder dyskeratosis congenita .

passage.title: Passage 1
passage.text:
(1). Inside the nucleus of cells, our genes are arranged along twisted, double-stranded molecules of DNA called “chromosomes.” At the ends of these chromosomes are stretches of DNA called telomeres, which protect our genetic data, make it possible for cells to divide, and hold some secrets about the processes behind age and cancer; in addition, telomeres are made up of a series of repetitive nucleotide sequences that play an important role in protecting our chromosomes and can also have an impact on aging in cells.

(2). The word “telomere” originates from two Greek words: “telos” meaning end, and “meros” meaning part. The role of telomeres in protecting human DNA was first documented by scientists in the 1930s. One of the most prominent scientists of this era was Barbara McClintock, an American cytogeneticist (a scientist who studies the relationship between chromosomes and cell behavior). After observing how chromosomes stick to their neighbors when their ends are eliminated, in 1933, McClintock determined the existence of a protective tip on the end of chromosomes. Owing to her contributions in the field of cytogenetics, McClintock was the first woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine.

(3). Without telomeres in place, chromosomes can either become damaged or fused with adjacent chromosomes, leading to cell degradation; since DNA in chromosomes forms instructions, which in turn tell cells how to behave, chromosomes are vital to the correct functioning of the human body. In fact, deoxyribonucleic acid can be found in the nucleus of each living cell; therefore, chromosomes, and the DNA they contain, are passed down from parents to each future generation. In this way, telomeres, given their important protective function for chromosomes, are an essential part of a healthy human body.

(4). The number of individual cells in our bodies does not remain consistent throughout our lives since cells are continually reproducing through the process of copying themselves. This process is necessary to grow new skin, maintain our bones, produce more blood, and generally maintain the state of our bodies. In cell reproduction, DNA molecules are preserved, whereas telomeres become shorter each time the cell is copied; this shortening is mitigated to some extent by the replenishing enzyme telomerase, also known as telomerase reverse transcriptase. However, after an extensive time, the telomeres found on our chromosomes become increasingly shorter.

(5). For the above reason, it has been said that the length of the telomeres found in a person’s cells is a true indicator of their biological age rather than their chronological age. Over our lifetime, repeated copying means that telomeres gradually shorten, and thus become more ineffectual. Telomere shortening is a manifestation of the natural aging process, but telomere shortening can also be a result of lifestyle factors, such as stress, smoking, obesity, and poor diet and exercise habits.

(6). The link between telomere length and cellular aging has been well documented by the scientific community. In total, over 10,000 scientific articles have been published about telomeres. Important discoveries relating to the nature of telomeres and the inability of chromosomes to replicate their ends were made in the 1970s, though scientists at the time were yet to make the connection between telomere shortening and fixed number of cell divisions. It was only later that a private study by the biotechnology company, Geron, clearly showed the connection between telomere shortening and cellular aging.

(7). Since Geron’s discovery, several important scientific studies have been made in the field of telomere research. In 2009, three scientists who established the link between the enzyme telomerase and telomere shortening were awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology/Medicine. The following year, Harvard Medical School released a study demonstrating that telomere shortening was a key cause of aging in cells.

(8). Scientists have found a strong link between many age-related diseases and shortened telomeres. A study conducted by the University of Utah showed that individuals over the age of 60, whose cells contained shorter telomeres, were three times more likely to die of heart disease and eight times more likely to die from infectious disease compared to participants in the same age group with longer telomeres. More specific impacts of telomere shortening documented by scientific studies include a weakened immune system, hardening of the arteries, type 2 diabetes, Alzheimer’s disease, and lowered bone density in women. It has also been documented that the rate of telomere shortening is more extreme in men compared to women.

(9). Furthermore, sufferers of the disease, dyskeratosis congenita experience an escalated rate of telomere shortening; documented effects of this disease not only include premature aging and death, but also increased incidence of severe infection, leukemia, intestinal disorder, cirrhosis (destructive scar tissue in the liver), and pulmonary fibrosis (a toughening of lung tissue, which can be fatal). Other symptoms of dyskeratosis congenita are impaired wound healing, bone softening, learning disabilities, as well as factors commonly associated with aging, such as balding or graying of the hair and skin spots. Scientists believe that the previously mentioned disorders, all of which involve tissues within cells that have a higher rate of reproduction, are a result of the presence of shortened telomeres.

(10). Extensive research has been done looking into the connection between telomeres and cancer. Increased cell reproduction is a common feature in many types of cancer; such a heightened rate of cell division results in an escalation of telomere shortening. This phenomenon has been especially observed in pancreatic, bone, prostate, bladder, lung, kidney, and head and neck cancers. In most instances, cells protect themselves by increasing telomerase production, thus keeping the telomeres from reducing. However, in extreme cases, such as escalation of cell reproduction can cause cell death due to the over-shortening of telomeres.

(11). Some researchers propose the use of telomerase as a method of cancer detection, but others go a step further and argue that a potential form of cancer treatment could involve halting the production of telomerase, thus eliminating cancer cells. One study conducted by scientists involved blocking telomerase activity within human breast and prostate cancer cells in the laboratory, which caused the cancer cells to die. However, the risks associated with this type of treatment include reduced fertility, impairment of the natural processes associated with healing wounds in the human body, and loss of blood and immune cell production.

(12). Some researchers have identified longer telomeres and telomerase as indicative of an increased risk of cancer. Conversely, others have argued that increased telomere length may protect against cancer, bearing in mind the link between cancer and shortened telomeres. Scientists continue to conduct studies about telomeres, including the possibilities and potential impacts of halting or reversing the process of telomere shortening. It is possible that temporary activation of telomerase could reverse the shortening of telomeres and slow the aging process in cells. Researchers have proposed drug treatments, gene therapy, and metabolic suppression as methods of reversing telomere shortening - however, these theories have yet to be definitively proven as effectual in humans. Optimistically, scientific studies have demonstrated a link between telomere lengthening and reversal of the signs of aging in species of mice and worms.

(13). One area of science that has sparked interest is studies measuring telomere length; a method for gauging telomere length in cells involves using an oligonucleotide probe and phosphoimager screen or autoradiographic film to determine the length of the telomeres on a chromosome. A second method is called the “Q-FISH methodology,” named so because it employs fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) to measure telomere length. However, a large amount of genetic material, up to 20 micrograms, is required to use this method, in addition to intensive labor; for these reasons, it is not a method widely employed in large-scale research. A third technique, called “single telomere elongation length analysis (STELA),” allows researchers to examine specific telomere ends, though this technique is only appropriate for shorter telomeres.

(14). Several scientists have questioned the efficacy of telomere length measurement, and it has been criticized as inappropriate for widespread clinical and personal use. Prominent scientist and Physiology/Medicine Nobel prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn co-founded a company offering clinical telomerase length measuring services, but later resigned, citing concerns over how telomere-related health processes were being controlled and managed. Nonetheless, many laboratories continue to offer telomere length measurement services as a commercial enterprise.

(15). A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases. Telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to the over-shortening of their telomeres. Using this process, insulin-producing cells could be engineered in the lab and transplanted to treat patients with diabetes; likewise, doctors could transplant muscle cells to treat those suffering from muscle dystrophy and transplant cartilage cells to treat arthritis. A further use for such lab-engineered cells could be to test new drugs and develop gene therapies.

question.text: What does the author mean by referring to “immortal” cells?

options.label: A.
options.text: Cells that contain a certain type of genetic material, making them more resilient

options.label: B.
options.text: Cells which can be copied many times per the cell culture process without degrading

options.label: C.
options.text: Cells with naturally occurring lengthened telomeres, making them resilient to aging

options.label: D.
options.text: Cells that mimic human cells and have been synthesized so they cannot be destroyed

options.label: E.
options.text: Cells that can never be destroyed

correct_answer_text: Cells which can be copied many times per the cell culture process without degrading

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should scan the passage for mention of the phrase “immortal cells” to ascertain in what context the author uses this phrase and, thus, what is their meaning. This phrase is mentioned only once in the fifteenth paragraph. Paragraph 15 reads: “A proposed area for further study and research involves using telomerase to assist with the mass production of so-called “immortal” cells. These cells could be cultured in the lab and transplanted into humans to treat a wide range of diseases; telomerase is an essential part of this process because it allows scientists to continue to culture and reproduce cells in the lab without such cells breaking down or becoming cancerous due to over-shortening of their telomeres.” The author describes immortal cells as those that can be reproduced without breaking down or degrading. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Cells that contain a certain type of genetic material, making them more resilient – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, the author states that immortal cells are made using telomerase and can be transplanted into human cells. This is not the same as the immortal cells having a certain genetic component that makes them more resilient. Option C. Cells with naturally occurring lengthened telomeres, making them resilient to aging – is incorrect because the author states that immortal cells are made using telomerase and can be transplanted into human cells. This is not the same as saying that immortal cells have naturally occurring long telomeres, which make them resistant to aging. Option D. Cells that mimic human cells and have been synthesized so they cannot be destroyed – is incorrect because the author says that immortal cells are made using telomerase and can be transplanted into human cells. This is not the same as saying that immortal cells mimic human cells and are synthesized with the purpose of resilience and longevity in mind. Option E. Cells that can never be destroyed – is incorrect because the author says that immortal cells are made using telomerase and can be transplanted into human cells. This is not the same as saying that immortal cells cannot be destroyed.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The cognitive processes associated with human vision are incredibly complex; what we call vision, sight, or “visual perception,” is the way in which we take in the information that our eyes receive, process, and interpret it. Such interpretations depend on individual cognitive processes and prior knowledge. The seemingly simple process of reading a passage of text, for instance, is, conversely, incredibly complicated, involving not only multiple subcomponents of vision, but also several distinct brain structures.

(2). The visual system refers to the various components in the body, that work together to achieve visual perception. The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focus the light so that it can be received by the retina. The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light, so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long range. The human visual system can perceive visible light between 370 and 730 nanometers in wavelength of the electromagnetic spectrum.

(3). The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Through the process of transduction, the retina converts energy from environmental stimuli - in this case light energy - to neural activity, which is a form of activity that the brain can understand and process.

(4). The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer, located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer - in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: What is the function of the photoreceptive cells contained in the retina?

options.label: D.
options.text: Transmit energy to the geniculate nucleus

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, note that the stem relates to the photoreceptive cells contained in the retina. It is thus logical to presume that a description of their purpose will be found in a paragraph describing the parts of the retina. Paragraph 3 reads: “The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response.” This tells us that the photoreceptive cells in the retina can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. They cells change energy into different forms – is incorrect because paragraph 3 states that the retina itself is designed to convert energy, but not the photoreceptive cells inside of the retina: “The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals.” Option C. These cells focus light, which is collected by the retina – is incorrect because paragraph 2 states that the cornea and the lens of the eye are responsible for focusing light, not the photoreceptive cells in the retina: “The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focuses the light so that it can be received by the retina.” Option D. These cells transmit information to the geniculate nucleus – is incorrect because paragraphs 5 and 6 describe the process involving the geniculate nucleus, which does not include input from the photoreceptive cells of the retina: “Here, the optic nerves partially cross so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right…. information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe.”

Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: Found on the back of the eye, the retina is a light-sensitive membrane. The brain makes use of learned knowledge to construct pictures while carrying out mental imagery.

options.label: C.
options.text: The first statement is TRUE, but the second is FALSE

options.label: D.
options.text: The first statement is FALSE, but the second statement is TRUE

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should ascertain whether the first statement is true; as this statement describes the retina, we should find a description of the retina in the passage and compare the statement in the question and the relevant information about the retina in the passage to deduce if the first statement is correct. Paragraph 2 describes the retina. This tells us that the retina IS a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye. As such, the first statement is true. Paragraph 2 reads: “The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye.” We should now ascertain whether the second statement in the question is true. As the second statement contains the phrase “mental imagery”, we should scan the passage for a paragraph or paragraphs that contain this phrase to deduce whether the second statement is true; only the final paragraph of the passage contains the phrase “mental imagery.” Paragraph 18 tells us that the brain DOES draw on learned knowledge of various elements to create an image while performing mental imagery. As such, the second statement is also true. Paragraph 18 reads: "…to conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.” Thus, both the first and second statements are TRUE. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Both statements are FALSE – is incorrect because both statements are correct. In the second paragraph of the passage, the author says that the retina is a membrane at the back of the eye. In the last paragraph, the author states that the brain draws on learned knowledge to create an image when dreaming (mental imagery). Option C. The first statement is TRUE, but the second is FALSE – is incorrect because the second statement is also true. The 18th paragraph of the passage states that the brain draws on learned knowledge to create an image when dreaming (mental imagery). Option D. The first statement is FALSE, but the second statement is TRUE – is incorrect because the first statement is true. In the second paragraph of the passage, the author says that the retina is a membrane at the back of the eye.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The cognitive processes associated with human vision are incredibly complex; what we call vision, sight, or “visual perception,” is the way in which we take in the information that our eyes receive, process, and interpret it. Such interpretations depend on individual cognitive processes and prior knowledge. The seemingly simple process of reading a passage of text, for instance, is, conversely, incredibly complicated, involving not only multiple subcomponents of vision, but also several distinct brain structures.

(2). The visual system refers to the various components in the body, that work together to achieve visual perception. The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focus the light so that it can be received by the retina. The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light, so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long range. The human visual system can perceive visible light between 370 and 730 nanometers in wavelength of the electromagnetic spectrum.

(3). The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Through the process of transduction, the retina converts energy from environmental stimuli - in this case light energy - to neural activity, which is a form of activity that the brain can understand and process.

(4). The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer, located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer - in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: Each of the following are parts of the eye involved in the process of visual perception EXCEPT one. Which is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage outlining the process of visual perception. As the passage is titled “vision,” it can be presumed that information closely related to the topic of vision, such as the process of visual perception, will be found early in the passage. Indeed, this information can be found in the second paragraph. In paragraph 2, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that the pupil, lens, cornea, and retina are all involved in the process of visual perception, but the iris is not listed. “The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina , a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focuses the light so that it can be received by the retina.” Thus, the iris is not involved in the process of visual perception. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Lens – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, when the author describes the vision process, they mention that the lens is involved. Option B. Pupil – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, when the author describes the vision process, they mention that the pupil is involved. Option D. Retina – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, when the author describes the vision process, they mention that the retina is involved. Option E. Cornea – is incorrect because in paragraph 2, when the author describes the vision process, they mention that the cornea is involved.

question.text: What is the author’s outlook regarding training our abilities in visual perception?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should first locate the paragraph in the passage that discusses vision training; this can be found in the fifteenth paragraph. Paragraph 15 reads: “There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.” Next, we should pay close attention to the author’s wording in this paragraph to ascertain their attitude and match it to one of the descriptors in the answer choices. If we note that the author uses language such as “there is some argument” and “purportedly,” we can deduce that the author is skeptical about vision training. Thus, the author’s attitude towards training our abilities in visual perception is skeptical. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Cynical – is incorrect because, when the author mentions vision training in paragraph 15, they do not seem distrustful of the information they are presenting. Therefore, since the word cynical does not best describe the author’s attitude, it is incorrect. Option B. Indifferent – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, having an indifferent attitude means having no particular interest in a subject matter. The first piece of evidence against the claim that the author is indifferent towards vision training is the fact that they chose to mention it at all in the passage; if they mentioned it, they wish to comment on it and are thus not indifferent. Secondly, the author uses skeptical language when they comment that visual training services falsely purport to improve vision; once again, this shows that the author has an opinion and is thus not indifferent. Option C. Critical – is incorrect because a critical attitude would mean that the author of the passage disapproves of vision training, and this does not seem to be the case – paragraph 15 demonstrates that the author seems more in doubt about the effectiveness of this training but does not necessarily disapprove of its use. Option D. Solemn – is incorrect because solemn means conveying a serious attitude when discussing a subject. This is not the case here, as, based on paragraph 15, the author casts doubt on the effectiveness of vision treatment but does not engage in a serious discussion of its pros and cons.
