Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: According to the passage, what is a transducer?

options.label: A.
options.text: A specialized cell in the retina

options.label: B.
options.text: A structure involved in neural processing

options.label: C.
options.text: A mechanism that circulates blood to sensory organs

options.label: D.
options.text: A tissue that converts heat to useful energy

options.label: E.
options.text: A device that converts energy from one form to another

correct_answer_text: A device that converts energy from one form to another

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, locate the first instance of the word “transducer” in the passage; the definition of this word will most likely follow its introduction. Paragraph 3 contains this word and reads: “The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another).” This tells us that a transducer is a device that converts energy from one form to another. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A part of the retina – is incorrect because, while the retina is described as a transducer, this is not the definition of a transducer itself. Option B. A part of the brain – is incorrect because, while the retina, an example of a transducer, is a part of the brain, this is not the definition of a transducer itself. Option C. A device that transports blood to the eye – is incorrect because there is no such device described in the passage; thus, this is not the definition of a transducer. Option D. A tissue that converts heat to useful energy – is incorrect because there is no such tissue described in the passage; thus, this is not the definition of a transducer.

The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light, so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long range. The human visual system can perceive visible light between 370 and 730 nanometers in wavelength of the electromagnetic spectrum.

(3). The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Through the process of transduction, the retina converts energy from environmental stimuli - in this case light energy - to neural activity, which is a form of activity that the brain can understand and process.

(4). The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer, located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. (8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. (13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. question.text: A woman suffers from visceral, terrifying hallucinations that cage her mind in a distorted illusion. She can recognize parts of the visuals but not the objects. Which concurrent conditions might she have?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should search the passage to find the description of each disorder mentioned in the option choices, then match the symptoms of said disorders to those experienced by the woman in the question at hand. Paragraph 11 describes perceptive and associative agnosia: “ Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object as a whole; those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is…they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.” Paragraph 13 describes Charles-Bonnet Syndrome: “Sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome...lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time; without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a...sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.” Paragraph 14 describes a comparison between schizophrenia and Charles-Bonnet Syndrome: “Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia; however, an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.” Broken down, the symptoms of each disorder are as follows: If we compare the above symptoms of each disorder to the symptoms experienced by the woman in the question (visceral, terrifying hallucinations that cage her mind in a distorted illusion, recognizing parts of visuals but not the objects themselves), we can see that she DOES think the hallucinations are real, so one of her disorders might be schizophrenia. If we note that she can recognize PARTS of visuals but NOT whole objects, the other disorder from which she suffers might be perceptive agnosia. Thus, the woman may have schizophrenia and perceptive agnosia. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Charles-Bonnet Syndrome and perceptive agnosia – is incorrect , as the question stem says that the woman feels caged in by her hallucinations; therefore, she does not know that they are illusionary. For this reason, she cannot have Charles-Bonnet Syndrome. Option C. Schizophrenia and associative agnosia – is incorrect because associative agnosia patients have functional sight but cannot interpret the information being received. These patients can see objects entirely but cannot recognize these objects. Based on the question stem, the woman can only recognize parts of visuals, not the whole visuals - thus, she more likely has perceptive agnosia. Option D. Charles-Bonnet Syndrome and associative agnosia – is incorrect, as the question stem says that the woman feels caged in by her hallucinations; she does not know they are not real. Thus, she cannot have Charles-Bonnet Syndrome. Associative agnosia patients have functional sight but cannot interpret the information received; these patients can see objects entirely but cannot recognize them. Based on the question stem, the woman can only recognize parts of visuals, not the whole visuals - thus, she more likely has perceptive agnosia. Option E. Schizophrenia and visual agnosia – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, the author breaks down visual agnosia into two types: perceptive and associative. The question at hand should be answered with a more specific diagnosis of one of these types.

question.text: Which of the following represents the sequence, in the correct order, in which information is passed on during the process of visual perception?

options.label: A.
options.text: Optic nerve, occipital lobe, ganglion cells, thalamus

options.label: B.
options.text: Optic nerve, ganglion cells, thalamus, occipital lobe

options.label: C.
options.text: Ganglion cells, occipital lobe, optic nerve, thalamus

options.label: D.
options.text: Ganglion cells, optic nerve, thalamus, occipital lobe

options.label: E.
options.text: Ganglion cells, thalamus, occipital lobe, optic nerve

correct_answer_text: Ganglion cells, optic nerve, thalamus, occipital lobe

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage describing the process of visual perception; the fifth and sixth paragraphs of the passage discuss this process. Paragraph 5 reads: “ Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer; in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right. “ Paragraph 6 reads: “…the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe .” Together, these paragraphs tell us that, during the process of visual perception, information is passed in the following order: ganglion cells, optic nerve, thalamus, and occipital lobe. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Optic nerve, occipital lobe, ganglion cells, thalamus – is incorrect because the information is passed on from ganglion cells, optic nerve, the thalamus, and then occipital lobe, based on paragraphs 5 and 6. Option B. Optic nerve, ganglion cells, thalamus, occipital lobe – is incorrect because the information is passed on from ganglion cells, optic nerve, the thalamus, and then occipital lobe, based on paragraphs 5 and 6. Option C. Ganglion cells, occipital lobe, optic nerve, thalamus – is incorrect because the information is passed on from ganglion cells, optic nerve, the thalamus, and then occipital lobe, based on paragraphs 5 and 6. Option E. Ganglion cells, thalamus, occipital lobe, optic nerve – is incorrect because the information is passed on from ganglion cells, optic nerve, the thalamus, and then occipital lobe, based on paragraphs 5 and 6.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The cognitive processes associated with human vision are incredibly complex; what we call vision, sight, or “visual perception,” is the way in which we take in the information that our eyes receive, process, and interpret it. Such interpretations depend on individual cognitive processes and prior knowledge. The seemingly simple process of reading a passage of text, for instance, is, conversely, incredibly complicated, involving not only multiple subcomponents of vision, but also several distinct brain structures.

(2). The visual system refers to the various components in the body, that work together to achieve visual perception. The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focus the light so that it can be received by the retina. The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light, so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long range. The human visual system can perceive visible light between 370 and 730 nanometers in wavelength of the electromagnetic spectrum.

(3). The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Through the process of transduction, the retina converts energy from environmental stimuli - in this case light energy - to neural activity, which is a form of activity that the brain can understand and process.

(4). The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer, located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer - in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: Globally, approximately how many women suffer from color vision deficiency?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should note that the stem relates to a type of visual disorder (color vision deficiency). Thus, we should search the passage for the section discussing vision disorders. Paragraphs 9-16 discuss these disorders, but only paragraph 13 mentions color vision deficiency. It reads: “Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world . Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red).” This tells us that approximately 1 in 200 women in the world is impacted by color vision deficiency. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. 1 in 12 – is incorrect because paragraph 13 states that this is the approximate number of men, not women, impacted by color vision deficiency. “Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world.” Option B. 1 in 50 – is incorrect because paragraph 13 states that approximately 1 in 200 women, not 1 in 50 women, are impacted by color vision deficiency. “Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world.” Option D. 1 in 10 – is incorrect because paragraph 13 states that approximately 1 in 200 women, not 1 in 10 women, are impacted by color vision deficiency. “Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world.”

question.text: Where is all sensory information directed in the process of visual perception?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage describing the process of visual perception. Paragraph 6 reads: “Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe; the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.” This tells us that all sensory information is sent to the visual association cortex in the process of visual perception. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Optic nerve – is incorrect because the optic nerve is a part of the vision process but is not where all the sensory information is sent. Paragraph 5 states: “After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain.” Option B. Optic chiasma – is incorrect because the optic chiasma is a part of the vision process but is not where all the sensory information is sent. Paragraph 5 states: “After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain.” Option C. Lateral geniculate nucleus – is incorrect because the lateral geniculate nucleus is a part of the vision process but is not where all the sensory information is sent. Paragraph 6 states: “Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe.” Option D. Retina – is incorrect because the retina is where the vision process begins, not where all sensory information is sent. Paragraph 2 states: “The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells.”

To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: Following an accident, an individual is unable to recognize the faces of family members. What is the most likely cause?

options.label: A.
options.text: Distorted information being received by the brain

options.label: C.
options.text: Information being eliminated before it reaches the brain

options.label: D.
options.text: A complete dysfunction of cognitive processes

options.label: E.
options.text: An impaired ability to process visual information being received

correct_answer_text: An impaired ability to process visual information being received

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, consider that it states that an individual lost the ability to recognize faces after an accident; therefore, we should scan the passage for all mention of vision disorders and match the symptoms of the accident victim in the question to one of these disorders. Vision disorders and conditions are discussed in paragraphs 9–16. In paragraph 13, the author mentions the statement below. This tells us that Prosopagnosia refers to the inability to recognize faces, which is caused by damaged cognitive processes impairing the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received. “Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text)…each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.” Thus, the individual in the question stem likely has prosopagnosia, a condition caused by an impaired ability to process visual information being received. Therefore, Option E is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Distorted information being received by the brain – is incorrect because the author attributes this cause to Charles-Bonnet Syndrome in paragraph 14: “Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.” Option B. Damage sustained to perceptive organs – is incorrect because the author states that this type of damage can cause blindness: “…for example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness.” The accident victim in the question stem is not blind or partially blind; thus, this answer is incorrect. Option C. Information being eliminated before it reaches the brain – is incorrect because the author attributes this cause to Charles-Bonnet Syndrome in paragraph 14: “Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.” Option D. A complete dysfunction of cognitive processes – is incorrect because the accident victim’s symptoms in the question do NOT describe a complete dysfunction of cognitive processes; the only symptom mentioned is an inability to recognize familiar faces.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The cognitive processes associated with human vision are incredibly complex; what we call vision, sight, or “visual perception,” is the way in which we take in the information that our eyes receive, process, and interpret it. Such interpretations depend on individual cognitive processes and prior knowledge. The seemingly simple process of reading a passage of text, for instance, is, conversely, incredibly complicated, involving not only multiple subcomponents of vision, but also several distinct brain structures.

(2). The visual system refers to the various components in the body, that work together to achieve visual perception. The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focus the light so that it can be received by the retina. The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light, so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long range. The human visual system can perceive visible light between 370 and 730 nanometers in wavelength of the electromagnetic spectrum.

(3). The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Through the process of transduction, the retina converts energy from environmental stimuli - in this case light energy - to neural activity, which is a form of activity that the brain can understand and process.

(4). The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer, located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer - in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: What would an individual with red photopigments located inside green cone receptors perceive when seeing a red object?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the paragraph in the passage that provides the most details about color vision disorders. Paragraph 12 provides the most information about color vision disorders. It reads: “Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red).” Thus, according to the passage, when an individual sees a blue light, this causes the blue photopigment molecule located inside the photoreceptor to split. As a result, the red photoreceptor becomes activated, transmitting a signal that red light is being perceived. Hence, an individual with red photopigments located inside green cone receptors would perceive a green object when viewing a red object. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. A red object – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, when someone sees a red light, the wavelength splits the red photopigment molecule inside the green photoreceptor, triggering the green photoreceptor to signal that green light is being perceived. Thus, the person would see green, not red. Option B. A cyan object –  is incorrect because, when someone sees a red light, the wavelength splits the red photopigment molecule inside the green photoreceptor, triggering the green photoreceptor to signal that green light is being perceived. Thus, the person would see green, not cyan. Option D. A white object – is incorrect because, when someone sees a red light, the wavelength splits the red photopigment molecule inside the green photoreceptor, triggering the green photoreceptor to signal that green light is being perceived. Thus, the person would see green, not white. Option E. A black object – is incorrect because, when someone sees a red light, the wavelength splits the red photopigment molecule inside the green photoreceptor, triggering the green photoreceptor to signal that green light is being perceived. Thus, the person would see green, not black.

question.text: What parts of the brain are involved in assessing the characteristics of a visual object?

options.label: A.
options.text: Occipital lobe, hypothalamus, and the temporal lobe

options.label: B.
options.text: Parietal lobe, hypothalamus, and the cerebral cortex

options.label: C.
options.text: Cerebral cortex, occipital lobe, and the temporal lobe

options.label: D.
options.text: Parietal lobe, temporal lobe, and the occipital lobe

options.label: E.
options.text: Hypothalamus, cerebral cortex, and the parietal lobe

correct_answer_text: Parietal lobe, temporal lobe, and the occipital lobe

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, locate the paragraph or paragraphs in the passage outlining the visual process. Paragraph 7 begins with, “Our process of vision involves…” Thus, we can presume that this will be the section of the passage that begins the discussion on the visual process. It reads: “The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics…” A description of the vision process continues in paragraph 8. It reads: “Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe , the temporal lobe , and the parietal lobe .” Altogether, paragraphs 7 and 8 tell us that the parts of the brain involved in assessing the characteristics of a visual object are the parietal lobe, temporal lobe, and occipital lobe. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Occipital lobe, hypothalamus, and the temporal lobe – is incorrect because this option mentions the hypothalamus, which, according to the passage, is not involved in completing the visual picture. Option B. Parietal lobe, hypothalamus, and the cerebral cortex – is incorrect because according to the passage, none of the parts of the brain mentioned in this option choice are involved in completing the visual picture. Option C. Cerebral cortex, occipital lobe, and the temporal lobe – is incorrect because this option choice mentions the cerebral cortex, which, according to the passage, is not involved in completing the visual picture. Option E. Hypothalamus, cerebral cortex, and the parietal lobe – is incorrect because this option choice mentions the hypothalamus and cerebral cortex, which, according to the passage, are not involved in completing the visual picture.

Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: Which of the following most accurately describes colour vision deficiency?

options.label: A.
options.text: An abnormality in the rod receptors found in the inner cell layer of the retina

options.label: B.
options.text: An abnormality in the cone receptors found in the inner cell layer of the retina

options.label: C.
options.text: An abnormality in the rod receptors found in the middle cell layer of the retina

options.label: D.
options.text: An abnormality in the rod receptors found in the outer cell layer of the retina

options.label: E.
options.text: An abnormality in the cone receptors found in the outer cell layer of the retina

correct_answer_text: An abnormality in the cone receptors found in the inner cell layer of the retina

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we need to ascertain which answer choice COULD be correct and thus has the potential to describe colour vision deficiency; as each of the answer choices given mentions the retina, we should first locate a description of this part of the eye in the passage. Paragraph 4 describes the retina. This tells us that photoreceptors are found in the inner layer of the retina, not the outer layer and that cone photoreceptors perceive colour, not rod receptors. It reads: “The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer, and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception).” Next, we should search the passage for any description of colour vision deficiency. Vision disorders are discussed in paragraphs 9–14; by scanning each of these paragraphs, it can be noted that paragraph 12 provides a brief description of color vision deficiency. It reads: “Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell…” Thus, together paragraphs 4 and 9 tell us that colour vision deficiency is best described as an abnormality in the cone receptors found in the inner cell layer of the retina. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. An abnormality in the rod receptors found in the inner cell layer of the retina – is incorrect because cone photoreceptors have photopigment molecules, not rod cells. Thus, color vision deficiency involves cones, not rods. Option C. An abnormality in the rod receptors found in the middle cell layer of the retina – is incorrect because cone photoreceptors have photopigment molecules, not rod cells. Thus, color vision deficiency involves cones, not rods. Additionally, as stated in paragraph 4, photoreceptor cells are found in the inner layer of the retina, not the middle layer. Option D. An abnormality in the rod receptors found in the outer cell layer of the retina – is incorrect because cone photoreceptors have photopigment molecules, not rod cells. Thus, color vision deficiency involves cones, not rods. Additionally, as stated in paragraph 4, photoreceptor cells are found in the inner layer of the retina, not the middle layer. Option E. An abnormality in the cone receptors found in the outer cell layer of the retina – is incorrect because, while it is correct that the cone layers are abnormal in this case, cone cells contain photoreceptors, which, according to paragraph 4, are found in the inner layer of the retina.

passage.title: Passage 2
passage.text:
(1). The cognitive processes associated with human vision are incredibly complex; what we call vision, sight, or “visual perception,” is the way in which we take in the information that our eyes receive, process, and interpret it. Such interpretations depend on individual cognitive processes and prior knowledge. The seemingly simple process of reading a passage of text, for instance, is, conversely, incredibly complicated, involving not only multiple subcomponents of vision, but also several distinct brain structures.

(2). The visual system refers to the various components in the body, that work together to achieve visual perception. The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focus the light so that it can be received by the retina. The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light, so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long range. The human visual system can perceive visible light between 370 and 730 nanometers in wavelength of the electromagnetic spectrum.

(3). The retina is a part of the brain and is designed to be a transducer (a device that converts energy from one form to another) for the conversion of light into neuronal signals. It contains photoreceptive cells, which can detect photons of light and produce neural impulses in response. Through the process of transduction, the retina converts energy from environmental stimuli - in this case light energy - to neural activity, which is a form of activity that the brain can understand and process.

(4). The retina is composed of three different cell layers: a photoreceptor layer, a bipolar cell layer and a ganglion cell layer. The photoreceptor layer is the inner layer, located at the very back of the eye. This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer - in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: How does the visual disorder "akinetopsia" affect an individual's vision?

options.label: A.
options.text: The sufferer is unable to see colors

options.label: B.
options.text: The sufferer is unable to see movement

options.label: C.
options.text: The sufferer cannot recognize familiar faces

correct_answer_text: The sufferer is unable to see movement

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should note that the stem relates to a type of visual disorder (akinetopsia). Thus, we should search the passage for the section discussing vision disorders. Paragraphs 9–16 discuss these disorders, but only paragraph 13 mentions akinetopsia. It reads: “Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world.” This tells us that akinetopsia causes an inability to see movement. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. The sufferer is unable to see colors – is incorrect because this would be caused by color vision deficiency, not akinetopsia. According to paragraph 13, “Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world.” Option C. The sufferer cannot recognize familiar faces – is incorrect because paragraph 13 attributes this to prosopagnosia, not akinetopsia: “Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text).” Option D. The sufferer cannot interpret text – is incorrect because paragraph 13 attributes this to Alexia, not akinetopsia: “Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text).”
