question.text: Based on the passage, each of the following causes blindness EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

options.label: D.
options.text: Eye surgery causing optic nerve damage

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, we should locate the section of the passage discussing visual disorders, such as blindness. If we note that paragraphs 9–14 discuss visual disorders, we should scan each of these paragraphs for mentions of blindness. Paragraph 9 reads: “…for example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve , or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma , diabetes mellitus , and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.” This tells us that optic nerve damage, diabetes mellitus, and brain injuries can cause blindness; as concussion and stroke can lead to brain injuries , the only option NOT listed in paragraph 9 is spinal cord injury . Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Stroke – is incorrect because a stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or severely reduced, causing brain tissues to be deprived of oxygen and nutrients and leading to potential brain injury, which is listed in paragraph 9 as a possible cause of blindness. Option C. Concussion from an accident – is incorrect because according to paragraph 9, any accident that causes a brain injury can lead to blindness; since accidents are mentioned in paragraph 9 as possible causes of blindness, concussion from an accident cannot be the answer. Option D. Eye surgery causing optic nerve damage – is incorrect because, according to paragraph 9, any accident that causes damage to perceptive organs can cause blindness; since accidents to perceptive organs are mentioned in paragraph 9 as possible causes of blindness, eye surgery causing optic nerve damage cannot be the answer. Option E. Diabetes Mellitus – is incorrect because, according to paragraph 9, diabetes mellitus CAN cause blindness: “For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus, and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.”

This layer’s photoreceptive cells can be divided into two types: rod photoreceptors, of which the function is to perceive objects in low light, and cone photoreceptors (responsible for color perception). There are three types of cone receptors: red, green, and blue. Cone photoreceptors contain photopigment molecules that respond to specific wavelengths of light hitting the cone photoreceptors and each wavelength corresponds to the specific color of the photoreceptor cell. When a specific wavelength hits the photoreceptor, the photopigment molecule splits into two; this action causes a message to be sent to the second cell layer of the retina (the bipolar cell layer), which then sends a message to the final layer of cells in the retina, known as the “ganglion layer.”

(5). After the photoreceptor cells in the retina receive light energy and convert it into a neural impulse, the ganglion cells then send messages using the optic nerve, through the optic chiasma and to the brain. Ganglion cells are constantly firing, even when they do not receive stimulus, and the rate of firing increases or decreases depending on the message received from the bipolar cell layer - in this way, information is transmitted to the brain. The optic chiasma is located at the bottom of the brain, directly below the hypothalamus. Here, the optic nerves partially cross, so that the signals received from the right retina are sent to the left hemisphere, and those from the left retina are sent to the right.

(6). Information is then received by the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus in the brain before it is sent to the visual association cortex in the occipital lobe. Following this, the occipital lobe puts together all the sensory information that was perceived by the visual system. In short, the visual association cortex allows us to perceive objects and interpret the entirety of the visual scenes we encounter.

(7). The process of vision involves taking in and assessing a long list of characteristics. For instance, when we look at an object, to determine what we are looking at our brain uses our eyes and optic nerve to process the size of the object, its shape, position, lighting, contrast, color, and dimensions, in addition to whether the object is moving or stationary, how many of the same object are present at a given time, what the object is used for, and its name (all this information is processed within a fraction of a second).

(8). Rather than passively observing information, the brain uses data such as prior knowledge and logic to complete visual pictures; these processes are carried out in specific areas of the occipital lobe, the temporal lobe, and the parietal lobe.

(9). Good vision requires all the areas of the brain involved in visual perception to work together effectively, but there are a range of pathologies and disorders that can impact our visual perception. For example, damage to perceptive organs, such as parts of the eye, the optic nerve, or the parts of the brain involved in vision, can cause partial or total blindness. Glaucoma, diabetes mellitus and brain injury can affect visual perception and are some of the more common causes of blindness.

(10). As vision is a complex process involving multiple areas of the brain, damage to any of these areas can hinder the vision process at its various stages, thus negatively impacting visual perception; such faults in these processes are linked to different disorders. One example is known as Visual Agnosia, which is the inability to recognize previously learned objects, despite the individual with the disorder having functioning sight. There are two types of Visual Agnosia: Perceptive Agnosia and Associative Agnosia.

(11). Sufferers of Perceptive Agnosia can identify the components of an object but cannot interpret the object, while those with Associative Agnosia can process the whole object but cannot understand what it is. Although they do have functional sight, sufferers of Associative Agnosia experience a type of blindness, as they cannot interpret the information that is being received using their eyes.

(12). An individual diagnosed with Perceptive Agnosia finds it challenging to recognize common sights such as body parts, buildings, and animals. Sufferers of the disorder encounter difficulties identifying manipulated items, such as blocks, puzzles, or beads. Those with Perceptive Agnosia cannot draw objects or copy figures. This disorder results from damage to the sections of the brain, including the occipital, temporal, and parietal lobes, which are responsible for remembrance of crucial everyday items and their purposes. On the other hand, individuals with Associative Agnosia find it difficult to understand the meaning of what they are seeing. Unlike those with Perceptive Agnosia, they can draw a picture, but they cannot identify what they have drawn. They may mistake two objects of similar shape for one another, such as a rowing paddle and a cricket bat. Damage to the inferior occipitotemporal area of the brain, a section responsible for tasks including object recognition and visuospatial processing, causes this disorder.

(13). Additional vision disorders associated with damaged cognitive processes include Akinetopsia (the inability to see movement), Achromatopsia (the inability to see colors), Prosopagnosia (the inability to recognize learned faces) and Alexia (the inability to interpret text). Another common vision disorder is color vision deficiency, affecting approximately 1 in 12 men and 1 in 200 women in the world. Color vision deficiency, commonly known as color blindness, occurs when photopigment molecules are found in the incorrect photoreceptor cell (for example, if blue photopigments are located inside red cone receptors, the subject will perceive blue objects as red). Each of the mentioned disorders partially or fully impair the ability of an individual to effectively process visual information being received by the brain.

(14). Yet more visual disorders are associated with a disruption of information being received by the brain, disorders which either distort the information received by the brain or eliminate it completely. In some cases, a complete loss of vision may result. It is believed that the reason sufferers of Charles-Bonnet Syndrome, for example, lose the ability to appropriately receive visual information, is due to being without sight for an extended time - without sight, the brain does not receive any visual stimulation. Once a Charles-Bonnet sufferer’s sight is restored, the visual process, having been out of practice, may manifest hallucinations and visual illusions.

(15). Hallucinations caused by distortion of visual information received can also be found in syndromes such as Schizophrenia, but an important difference between sufferers of Schizophrenia and those affected by Charles-Bonnet Syndrome is that the latter can recognize that the hallucinations they are experiencing are not real.

(16). Individuals suffering from Charles-Bonnet syndrome may see less complex visions, like lines, patterns, and mosaics. They may also see more complex images, including people and places. The hallucinations perceived by those with the Charles-Bonnet may be in color or occur in black and white; these images can be still or moving, brief or prolonged, small or large. Charles-Bonnet syndrome is often diagnosed in the elderly as this is the portion of society statistically most likely to encounter issues with their vision. For instance, age-related macular degeneration is one condition in older people that can lead to Charles-Bonnet syndrome. Although sufferers of Charles-Bonnet are aware that their visions are not real, the visions can nonetheless cause distress since individuals may believe they are suffering from a disorder such as dementia. Additionally, the presence of the images may overlay objects in the sufferer’s external world, making it difficult to navigate one’s environment safely.

(17). There is some argument that, as a cognitive ability, our vision can be trained and augmented. Some research companies offer “visual perception training” services, which purportedly allow individuals to maintain or improve the performance of their sight by training the cognitive processes associated with vision to function better.

(18). Mental imagery is an example of a task involving the cognitive processes of visual perception that does not use external stimuli. Humans employ the use of mental imagery in many ways daily; mental imagery is extremely useful in strategic thinking, such as visualizing the potential outcomes of a situation. Mental imagery is also employed in creative processes, where the brain first imagines or visualizes what is to be created. To conduct mental imagery, the brain draws on its prior knowledge of various elements, such as faces, objects and shapes, as well as non-visual sensations such as smell and touch, to create a new image. Creating and forming mental images is also an essential part of dreaming.

question.text: An individual can no longer focus their visual perception at a variety of distances following a car accident. An injury to which part of the eye most likely caused this to occur?

explanation.concept_text: To answer this question, it is necessary to determine which part of the eye is responsible for focusing visual perception at a variety of distances. This can be accomplished by finding a description in the passage of each part of the eye listed in the option choices and systematically eliminating all those NOT responsible for focus. Paragraph 2 discusses the different parts of the eye. Based on this paragraph, only the lens is mentioned as being responsible for focusing vision at a variety of distances. It reads: “The process of vision begins when rays of light pass through the pupil of the eye and hit the retina, a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, activating receptor cells. This process is facilitated by the cornea - and subsequently the lens of the eye - which focuses the light so that it can be received by the retina. The lens can adapt to feedback signals it receives from the brain to adjust its thickness to effectively refract light so that it is focused onto the retina. It alters its thickness by changing shape to affect its curvature, which in turn adjusts the focal distance of the eye, meaning we can focus our visual perception at a variety of distances, from up close to long-range.” Thus, an injury to the lens most likely caused the symptoms of the individual in the question stem. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Iris – is incorrect because the iris is not mentioned anywhere in the passage. Option B. Cornea – is incorrect because the cornea is “a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, which activates receptor cells.” The injury described in the question stem relates to visual perception and focusing on various distances; thus, this is incorrect. Option D. Retina – is incorrect because, while this may seem correct, the retina is “a light-sensitive membrane at the back of the eye, which activates receptor cells,” whereas the lens focuses light. Damage to the retina would not result in a person being unable to focus visual perception at various distances; thus, this is incorrect. Option E. Pupil – is incorrect because the pupil is where the vision process begins, and rays of light pass through the pupil to hit the retina. Damage to the pupil would not result in a person being unable to focus visual perception at various distances; thus, this is incorrect.

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Koch’s Postulates are used to establish a causal link between microbe and disease. Building on the works of Friedrich Loeffler and Jakob Henle in the 19 th century, Robert Koch constructed guidelines that evaluated whether a specific microorganism causes a specific disease. While experimenting with the blood of cows that died from anthrax, Koch observed rod-shaped bacteria within the blood. Intrigued by their presence, Koch injected the infected blood into healthy mice. After observing how the mice fell ill and died from anthrax, Koch’s hypothesis that this bacterium caused the disease was conclusively supported. Consequently, Koch constructed four postulates that established the causal link between a microorganism and disease. These postulates revolutionized medicine and gave way to the understanding of germ theory. Using Koch’s Postulates, scientists have been able to definitively assign specific bacteria as the causative agents of several diseases including tuberculosis and cholera.

(2). The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals. A strict interpretation of this postulate would entail assuming that the infected individuals depict symptoms of the disease while healthy individuals do not. However, as Koch later discovered, asymptomatic diseases also exist. Thus, despite the presence of the microorganism, infected individuals can appear to be the same as healthy individuals.

(3). The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture. Pure culture means that only one strand of that microorganism is present. Evidently, when a healthy individual’s blood is sampled and a pure culture is attempted to be made, no growth of the suspected bacteria within the culture medium should be observed.

(4). The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual. Presumably, this newly infected individual would be expected to show symptoms that deviate from when it was healthy. However, once again the presence of asymptomatic diseases complicates this interpretation. Regardless, the individual should objectively demonstrate their infected status, which leads to the fourth postulate.

(5). The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism. By identifying this bacterium to be the same as the original, scientists can conclusively assert the causal link between this bacterium and the disease. In such a manner, Koch’s Postulates elucidate the etiology of diseases by linking them to specific microorganisms.

(6). Koch’s Postulates are a helpful tool that allows scientists to approach the causative agent of disease in a logical manner. These postulates have been used as a checklist when designing and implementing experiments to systematically arrive at causal relationships between microorganisms and diseases. For instance, a scientist approaching the etiology of salmonellosis using this paradigm may utilize two specimens- A and B. Specimen B is observed to have diarrhea and fever while no symptoms are observed for A. When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A. To definitively recognize that the disease individual B is experiencing is caused by this bacterium, the scientist will grow this salmonella enterica in pure culture. This culture will then be inoculated into a healthy Specimen C. If Specimen C develops symptoms identical to Specimen B’s, or more importantly, has the same bacterium as Specimen B in its blood, then the scientist can be certain that indeed this bacterium caused the disease. Figure 1 illustrates the results the scientist can obtain which will conclusively demonstrate the causal link between salmonella enterica and salmonellosis.

Figure 1: Effect of Inoculating Specimen C with Pure Culture Obtained from Specimen B. Blood sample obtained from Specimen C was analyzed to determine the growth of salmonella enterica. Diameter of colonies, in millimeters, represents bacterial growth with a greater diameter illustrating more proliferation of the bacterium. Positive control was pure salmonella enterica injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. Negative control was saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C.

(7). Nonetheless, there are limitations that exist with Koch’s Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases. As mentioned before, asymptomatic bacteria seem to violate the first postulate. The Bartonella species, for example, can live within the blood of infected individuals without causing disease. Additionally, these species have been found to cause a variety of phenotypically different diseases. Similarly, several infections are absent from the infected individual once symptoms develop. For example, Group A streptococcus infection is thought to cause rheumatic fever. However, once the lesions of rheumatic fever do appear, the infection is long gone. Thus, drawing one-to-one relationships between such species and the diseases they cause can prove to be difficult as they deviate from Koch’s Postulates.

(8). Furthermore, many pathogens are unable to grow in nutrient medium culture which appear to violate Koch’s second postulate. These include the Mollicute bacteria which causes a myriad of diseases in humans. Viruses as well, do not grow in cell-free media. Hence, isolating pathogens from the infected individual and growing it in pure culture may not always be feasible. Additionally, certain infectious organisms grow poorly in blood cultures. These include the Heaemophilus parainfluenzae, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella kingae. Although these pathogens can cause endocarditis in children, they are notoriously known to be difficult to isolate and grow in culture.

(9). It is also important to note that pathogenesis can be a multi-step process. Myocardial infarction for example, is the result of numerous conditions happening in sequence. Although bacterial infection is apart of this sequence, it is not the only thing that causes this disease. Thus, assigning the bacteria as the causative agent is erroneous. Likewise, the discovery of prions- nonliving agents that cause transmissible diseases in healthy individuals, complicates matters as it implies that living organisms do not need to be the cause of a disease. Hence, there are numerous limitations and exceptions when it comes to applying Koch’s Postulates to the study of diseases.

(10). Since, Koch’s Postulates are unable to account for many infectious diseases, other criteria, such as the Bradford Hill criteria, and advancements in DNA sequencing have largely replaced Koch’s Postulates in examining the etiology of infectious diseases. Regardless, the fact remains that Koch’s Postulates transformed the way scientists approached diseases by making them realize that something as small as microorganisms can indeed have large-scale effects.

question.text: The causative agent of a diseased organism is isolated and cultured before being inoculated into a healthy organism. If the healthy organism remains free of disease, which of Koch’s postulates is directly violated?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 4 states: “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” The question is presenting a scenario where a scientist has isolated a microorganism from a diseased individual and is inoculated it into a healthy individual. Despite the inoculation, this individual remains free of disease. This directly violates postulate 3 which requires that the inoculation causes the disease in the individual. Although postulate 4 may also seem like the correct answer because the scientist will be unable to re-isolate the organism from the inoculated individual, this is an indirect effect. Postulate 3 on the other hand, is being directly violated. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Postulate 1 – is incorrect because paragraph 2 states: “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” The first postulate addresses the difference between a healthy and diseased individual before inoculation has occurred. This postulate is the first step in identifying the causative agent. The question states that the “…causative agent of a diseased organism is isolated and cultured before being inoculated into a healthy organism,” which means that the causative agent has inoculated into another individual. Therefore, postulate 1 has already occurred and so, is not violated. Option B. Postulate 2 – is incorrect because in paragraph 3, the author writes, “The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” The second postulate focuses on what occurs before inoculation. The question states that “…causative agent of a diseased organism is isolated and cultured before being inoculated into a healthy organism,” which means that the causative agent has already been cultured and is ready for inoculation. Therefore, postulate 2 has occurred and so, is not violated. Option D. Postulate 4 – is incorrect because in paragraph 5, the author writes, “The final [fourth] postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism.” Although the question presents a scenario where the scientists will be unable to re-isolate the organism from the inoculated individual, this is an indirect effect. Paragraph 4 states: “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” The question asks which postulate is being directly violated. Considering the fact that the inoculated organism remains free of disease demonstrates that postulate 3 is directly violated whereas postulate 4 is indirectly violated.

question.text: Which of Koch’s Postulates are satisfied by the following sentence: The bacterium, Clostridium tetani, was found in the blood of the diseased mouse but it was missing in the healthy mouse.

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 2 states: “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” The question presents a scenario where two mice are being compared and the disease causing agent, Clostridium tetani, is only present in the first mice but not the second. Postulate 1 focuses on addressing the difference between healthy and diseased individuals. Thus, Postulate 1 is satisfied by this scenario. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Postulate 2 – is incorrect because “the second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” (Paragraph 3). The question however, presents a scenario where two mice are compared and one has the disease causing agent while the other does not. This observation satisfies the first postulate which focuses on comparing two organisms and their diseased state but does not satisfy Koch’s second postulate which focuses on growing the microorganism in pure culture. Since the scenario does not discuss pure cultures, but rather addresses the health state of two individuals, it is more in line with postulate 1. Option C. Both postulates 2 and 3 – is incorrect because ostulate 2 is not satisfied by the sentence because Postulate 2 focuses on growing the microorganism in pure culture as evidenced by paragraph 3 when it says, “…second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” The question however, presents a scenario where two mice are compared and one has the disease-causing agent while the other does not. This observation satisfies the first postulate which focuses on comparing two organisms and their diseased state but does not satisfy Koch’s second postulate which focuses on growing the microorganism in pure culture. Postulate 3 on the other hand, states that “…when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” (Paragraph 4). The scenario presented in the question can satisfy this postulate because the inoculated mice can be the one with the Clostridium tetani bacterium. However, since postulate 2 is not satisfied, this option is ultimately incorrect. Option D. None of the postulates – is incorrect because the question presents a scenario where two mice are being compared and the disease causing agent, Clostridium tetani, is only present in the first mice. Postulate 1 focuses on addressing the difference between healthy and diseased individuals as evidenced by paragraph 2 which says: “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” Thus, this scenario satisfies Postulate 1, making this option incorrect.

Since, Koch’s Postulates are unable to account for many infectious diseases, other criteria, such as the Bradford Hill criteria, and advancements in DNA sequencing have largely replaced Koch’s Postulates in examining the etiology of infectious diseases. Regardless, the fact remains that Koch’s Postulates transformed the way scientists approached diseases by making them realize that something as small as microorganisms can indeed have large-scale effects.

options.label: D.
options.text: Specimen C developed diarrhea and fever

explanation.concept_text: The negative control in an experiment is the condition that is expected to NOT show any changes. Figure 1’s caption describes the negative control as a saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. Hence, the negative control specimen is expected to have NO growth of salmonella enterica , which is exactly what the graph illustrates. If the Specimen B’s Pure Culture line was the same as the negative control, it would mean that Specimen C had no growth of salmonella enterica despite being inoculated by specimen B’s pure culture. This would directly violate postulate 3 because paragraph 4 states: “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” Koch’s third postulate is violated in this scenario because the inoculation did NOT cause the disease in Specimen C. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.

When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A.” If Specimen C developed diarrhea and fever it would indicate that they developed salmonellosis. However, the question states that Specimen B’s Pure Culture line is the same as the negative control line. If the Specimen B’s Pure Culture line was the same as the negative control, it would mean that Specimen C had no growth of salmonella enterica despite being inoculated by specimen B’s pure culture. Therefore, in this scenario Specimen C would be expected to NOT have salmonellosis because they would have NO salmonella enterica in their blood.

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Koch’s Postulates are used to establish a causal link between microbe and disease. Building on the works of Friedrich Loeffler and Jakob Henle in the 19 th century, Robert Koch constructed guidelines that evaluated whether a specific microorganism causes a specific disease. While experimenting with the blood of cows that died from anthrax, Koch observed rod-shaped bacteria within the blood. Intrigued by their presence, Koch injected the infected blood into healthy mice. After observing how the mice fell ill and died from anthrax, Koch’s hypothesis that this bacterium caused the disease was conclusively supported. Consequently, Koch constructed four postulates that established the causal link between a microorganism and disease. These postulates revolutionized medicine and gave way to the understanding of germ theory. Using Koch’s Postulates, scientists have been able to definitively assign specific bacteria as the causative agents of several diseases including tuberculosis and cholera.

(2). The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals. A strict interpretation of this postulate would entail assuming that the infected individuals depict symptoms of the disease while healthy individuals do not. However, as Koch later discovered, asymptomatic diseases also exist. Thus, despite the presence of the microorganism, infected individuals can appear to be the same as healthy individuals.

(3). The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture. Pure culture means that only one strand of that microorganism is present. Evidently, when a healthy individual’s blood is sampled and a pure culture is attempted to be made, no growth of the suspected bacteria within the culture medium should be observed.

(4). The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual. Presumably, this newly infected individual would be expected to show symptoms that deviate from when it was healthy. However, once again the presence of asymptomatic diseases complicates this interpretation. Regardless, the individual should objectively demonstrate their infected status, which leads to the fourth postulate.

(5). The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism. By identifying this bacterium to be the same as the original, scientists can conclusively assert the causal link between this bacterium and the disease. In such a manner, Koch’s Postulates elucidate the etiology of diseases by linking them to specific microorganisms.

(6). Koch’s Postulates are a helpful tool that allows scientists to approach the causative agent of disease in a logical manner. These postulates have been used as a checklist when designing and implementing experiments to systematically arrive at causal relationships between microorganisms and diseases. For instance, a scientist approaching the etiology of salmonellosis using this paradigm may utilize two specimens- A and B. Specimen B is observed to have diarrhea and fever while no symptoms are observed for A. When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A. To definitively recognize that the disease individual B is experiencing is caused by this bacterium, the scientist will grow this salmonella enterica in pure culture. This culture will then be inoculated into a healthy Specimen C. If Specimen C develops symptoms identical to Specimen B’s, or more importantly, has the same bacterium as Specimen B in its blood, then the scientist can be certain that indeed this bacterium caused the disease. Figure 1 illustrates the results the scientist can obtain which will conclusively demonstrate the causal link between salmonella enterica and salmonellosis.

Figure 1: Effect of Inoculating Specimen C with Pure Culture Obtained from Specimen B. Blood sample obtained from Specimen C was analyzed to determine the growth of salmonella enterica. Diameter of colonies, in millimeters, represents bacterial growth with a greater diameter illustrating more proliferation of the bacterium. Positive control was pure salmonella enterica injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. Negative control was saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C.

(7). Nonetheless, there are limitations that exist with Koch’s Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases. As mentioned before, asymptomatic bacteria seem to violate the first postulate. The Bartonella species, for example, can live within the blood of infected individuals without causing disease. Additionally, these species have been found to cause a variety of phenotypically different diseases. Similarly, several infections are absent from the infected individual once symptoms develop. For example, Group A streptococcus infection is thought to cause rheumatic fever. However, once the lesions of rheumatic fever do appear, the infection is long gone. Thus, drawing one-to-one relationships between such species and the diseases they cause can prove to be difficult as they deviate from Koch’s Postulates.

(8). Furthermore, many pathogens are unable to grow in nutrient medium culture which appear to violate Koch’s second postulate. These include the Mollicute bacteria which causes a myriad of diseases in humans. Viruses as well, do not grow in cell-free media. Hence, isolating pathogens from the infected individual and growing it in pure culture may not always be feasible. Additionally, certain infectious organisms grow poorly in blood cultures. These include the Heaemophilus parainfluenzae, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella kingae. Although these pathogens can cause endocarditis in children, they are notoriously known to be difficult to isolate and grow in culture.

(9). It is also important to note that pathogenesis can be a multi-step process. Myocardial infarction for example, is the result of numerous conditions happening in sequence. Although bacterial infection is apart of this sequence, it is not the only thing that causes this disease. Thus, assigning the bacteria as the causative agent is erroneous. Likewise, the discovery of prions- nonliving agents that cause transmissible diseases in healthy individuals, complicates matters as it implies that living organisms do not need to be the cause of a disease. Hence, there are numerous limitations and exceptions when it comes to applying Koch’s Postulates to the study of diseases.

(10). Since, Koch’s Postulates are unable to account for many infectious diseases, other criteria, such as the Bradford Hill criteria, and advancements in DNA sequencing have largely replaced Koch’s Postulates in examining the etiology of infectious diseases. Regardless, the fact remains that Koch’s Postulates transformed the way scientists approached diseases by making them realize that something as small as microorganisms can indeed have large-scale effects.

question.text: Use Figure 1 to answer questions 36-37. Suppose blood sample from Specimen A was injected into Specimen C and the data was plotted onto Figure 1. How would this new line appear on the graph?

options.label: A.
options.text: Similar to the positive control line

options.label: B.
options.text: Similar to the negative control line

options.label: C.
options.text: Similar to the Specimen B’s Pure Culture line

options.label: D.
options.text: There is not enough information to answer this question

correct_answer_text: Similar to the negative control line

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 6 states: “For instance, a scientist approaching the etiology of salmonellosis using this paradigm may utilize two specimens- A and B. Specimen B is observed to have diarrhea and fever while no symptoms are observed for A. When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A.” Specimen A does not have any salmonella enterica in their blood. Since a sample of their blood was injected into Specimen C, NO salmonella enterica was transferred. Thus, specimen C in this scenario should have no growth of salmonella enterica. The negative control in an experiment is the condition that is expected to NOT show any changes. Figure 1’s caption describes the negative control as a saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. The negative control specimen has no growth of salmonella enterica, just like Specimen C in this scenario. Thus, this new line would be identical to the negative control line. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Similar to the positive control line – is incorrect because the positive control in an experiment is the condition that shows the expected results. Figure 1’s caption states that the positive control in the experiment is pure salmonella enterica injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. This specimen has a proliferation of salmonella enterica. However, paragraph 6 states that “…the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A.” So, Specimen A does not have any salmonella enterica in their blood. Since a sample of their blood was injected into Specimen C, NO salmonella enterica was transferred. Thus, specimen C in this scenario should have no growth of salmonella enterica. This is completely opposite than the positive control condition. Hence, the new line would NOT be similar to the positive control line. Option C. Similar to the Specimen B’s Pure Culture line – is incorrect because paragraph 6 states: “When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A.” Specimen B’s pure culture has salmonella enterica. This is also evidenced by Figure 1 because it depicts the Specimen B’s Pure Culture line as increasing which shows a proliferation of this bacterium. Specimen A on the other hand, has no traces of salmonella enterica. Thus, if a sample of Specimen A’s blood was injected into Specimen C it would not be similar to Specimen B’s Pure Culture line. Rather, it would show NO proliferation of salmonella enterica which is most similar to the negative control line. Option D. There is not enough information to answer this question – is incorrect because there IS enough information to deduce the answer because paragraph 6 states that “When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A.” Thus, we know that Specimen A does NOT have any salmonella enterica in their blood. Since a sample of their blood was injected into Specimen C, NO salmonella enterica was transferred and so, Specimen C in this scenario should have no growth of salmonella enterica. This scenario is identical to the negative control condition where no growth of salmonella enterica is observed. Therefore, the new line would be identical to the negative control line.

question.text: Each of the following disorders are the result of bacteria, EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 1 states: “While experimenting with the blood of cows that died from anthrax , Koch observed rod-shaped bacteria within the blood. Lastly, paragraph 6 states: “For instance, a scientist approaching the etiology of salmonellosis using this paradigm may utilize two specimens- A and B. To definitively recognize that the disease individual B is experiencing is caused by this bacterium, the scientist will grow this salmonella enterica in pure culture.” Thus, salmonellosis is caused by the salmonella enterica bacterium. Ebola is never mentioned in the passage and so, there is no evidence to indicate that it is caused by bacteria. The other diseases however, are clearly attributed to bacteria. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.

question.text: A scientist obtains agarose gel to use as a medium to grow a pure culture of Legionella pneumophila after they isolated this bacterium from a diseased individual. What postulate are they attempting to satisfy?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 3 states: “The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” Evidently, Postulate 2 is concerned with growing a pure culture of a bacterium after it has been isolated from a diseased individual. Since the scientist in the question is obtaining tools to grow a pure culture of the isolated Legionella pneumophila , they are aiming to satisfy the second postulate. Therefore, Option B is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Postulate 1 – is incorrect because in paragraph 2 the author writes, “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” Postulate 1 is concerned with comparing two individuals and determining the presence of bacterium in the diseased individuals. There is no mention of growing a pure culture. Arguably, a scientist may obtain a pure culture to identify and determine the bacterium of the diseased individual, however, this is not necessarily a requirement of Postulate 1. This postulate merely requires that the infected individual must have the bacterium and that the healthy individual must not. Postulate 2 on the other hand, specifically requires a pure culture to be made. Therefore, this option is incorrect because this postulate does not focus on growing a pure culture. Option C. Postulate 3 – is incorrect because in paragraph 4 the author writes, “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” Postulate 3 is concerned with inoculating a new individual with the causative agent. There is no mention of growing a pure culture making this option incorrect. Option D. None of the postulates – is incorrect because in paragraph 3 the author writes, “The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” Postulate 2 is concerned with growing a pure culture of a bacterium after it has been isolated from a diseased individual. Since the scientist in the question is obtaining tools to grow a pure culture of the isolated Legionella pneumophila, they are aiming to satisfy the second postulate.

This culture will then be inoculated into a healthy Specimen C. If Specimen C develops symptoms identical to Specimen B’s, or more importantly, has the same bacterium as Specimen B in its blood, then the scientist can be certain that indeed this bacterium caused the disease. Figure 1 illustrates the results the scientist can obtain which will conclusively demonstrate the causal link between salmonella enterica and salmonellosis.

Figure 1: Effect of Inoculating Specimen C with Pure Culture Obtained from Specimen B. Blood sample obtained from Specimen C was analyzed to determine the growth of salmonella enterica. Diameter of colonies, in millimeters, represents bacterial growth with a greater diameter illustrating more proliferation of the bacterium. Positive control was pure salmonella enterica injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. Negative control was saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C.

(7). Nonetheless, there are limitations that exist with Koch’s Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases. As mentioned before, asymptomatic bacteria seem to violate the first postulate. The Bartonella species, for example, can live within the blood of infected individuals without causing disease. Additionally, these species have been found to cause a variety of phenotypically different diseases. Similarly, several infections are absent from the infected individual once symptoms develop. For example, Group A streptococcus infection is thought to cause rheumatic fever. However, once the lesions of rheumatic fever do appear, the infection is long gone. Thus, drawing one-to-one relationships between such species and the diseases they cause can prove to be difficult as they deviate from Koch’s Postulates.

(8). Furthermore, many pathogens are unable to grow in nutrient medium culture which appear to violate Koch’s second postulate. These include the Mollicute bacteria which causes a myriad of diseases in humans. Viruses as well, do not grow in cell-free media. Hence, isolating pathogens from the infected individual and growing it in pure culture may not always be feasible. Additionally, certain infectious organisms grow poorly in blood cultures. These include the Heaemophilus parainfluenzae, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella kingae. Although these pathogens can cause endocarditis in children, they are notoriously known to be difficult to isolate and grow in culture.

(9). It is also important to note that pathogenesis can be a multi-step process. Myocardial infarction for example, is the result of numerous conditions happening in sequence. Although bacterial infection is apart of this sequence, it is not the only thing that causes this disease. Thus, assigning the bacteria as the causative agent is erroneous. Likewise, the discovery of prions- nonliving agents that cause transmissible diseases in healthy individuals, complicates matters as it implies that living organisms do not need to be the cause of a disease. Hence, there are numerous limitations and exceptions when it comes to applying Koch’s Postulates to the study of diseases.

(10). Since, Koch’s Postulates are unable to account for many infectious diseases, other criteria, such as the Bradford Hill criteria, and advancements in DNA sequencing have largely replaced Koch’s Postulates in examining the etiology of infectious diseases. Regardless, the fact remains that Koch’s Postulates transformed the way scientists approached diseases by making them realize that something as small as microorganisms can indeed have large-scale effects.

question.text: What limitation exists with Koch’s Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases?

options.label: A.
options.text: Failure to consider the existence of symptomatic bacteria

options.label: B.
options.text: The establishment of only a weak link between microbe and disease

options.label: C.
options.text: Failure to acknowledge pathogens that are difficult to isolate in culture

options.label: D.
options.text: Recognition of how pathogenesis can be a multi-step process

correct_answer_text: Failure to acknowledge pathogens that are difficult to isolate in culture

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 8 states: “Furthermore, many pathogens are unable to grow in nutrient medium culture which appear to violate Koch’s second postulate. […] Hence, isolating pathogens from the infected individual and growing it in pure culture may not always be feasible. […] Although these pathogens can cause endocarditis in children, they are notoriously known to be difficult to isolate and grow in culture.” The author discusses the various limitations with Koch Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases. Amongst these is the fact that several pathogens are difficult to isolate and grow in culture but the postulates fail to take them into consideration. Therefore, Option C is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Failure to consider the existence of symptomatic bacteria – is incorrect because paragraph 7 states: “…there are limitations that exist with Koch’s Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases. As mentioned before, asymptomatic bacteria seem to violate the first postulate.” The postulates fail to consider asymptomatic bacteria; however, the option choice states symptomatic bacteria. As mentioned in paragraph 2, when applying the first postulate scientists compare healthy and infected individuals and observe how “…infected individuals depict symptoms of the disease while healthy individuals do not.” Thus, the postulates do address symptomatic bacteria. Option B. The establishment of only a weak link between microbe and disease – is incorrect because paragraph 1 states: “Koch’s Postulates are used to establish a causal link between microbe and disease. […] Using Koch’s Postulates, scientists have been able to definitively assign specific bacteria as the causative agents of several diseases including tuberculosis and cholera.” The author clearly writes how Koch’s postulates have been used to establish strong relationships between microbes and diseases. Option D. Failure to acknowledge pathogens that are difficult to isolate in culture – is incorrect because paragraph 9 states: “It is also important to note that pathogenesis can be a multi-step process. Myocardial infarction for example, is the result of numerous conditions happening in sequence. […] Thus, assigning the bacteria as the causative agent is erroneous. […] Hence, there are numerous limitations and exceptions when it comes to applying Koch’s Postulates to the study of diseases.” Therefore, the limitation is that the postulates do NOT recognize how pathogenesis is a multi-step process.

passage.title: Passage 3
passage.text:
(1). Koch’s Postulates are used to establish a causal link between microbe and disease. Building on the works of Friedrich Loeffler and Jakob Henle in the 19 th century, Robert Koch constructed guidelines that evaluated whether a specific microorganism causes a specific disease. While experimenting with the blood of cows that died from anthrax, Koch observed rod-shaped bacteria within the blood. Intrigued by their presence, Koch injected the infected blood into healthy mice. After observing how the mice fell ill and died from anthrax, Koch’s hypothesis that this bacterium caused the disease was conclusively supported. Consequently, Koch constructed four postulates that established the causal link between a microorganism and disease. These postulates revolutionized medicine and gave way to the understanding of germ theory. Using Koch’s Postulates, scientists have been able to definitively assign specific bacteria as the causative agents of several diseases including tuberculosis and cholera.

(2). The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals. A strict interpretation of this postulate would entail assuming that the infected individuals depict symptoms of the disease while healthy individuals do not. However, as Koch later discovered, asymptomatic diseases also exist. Thus, despite the presence of the microorganism, infected individuals can appear to be the same as healthy individuals.

(3). The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture. Pure culture means that only one strand of that microorganism is present. Evidently, when a healthy individual’s blood is sampled and a pure culture is attempted to be made, no growth of the suspected bacteria within the culture medium should be observed.

(4). The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual. Presumably, this newly infected individual would be expected to show symptoms that deviate from when it was healthy. However, once again the presence of asymptomatic diseases complicates this interpretation. Regardless, the individual should objectively demonstrate their infected status, which leads to the fourth postulate.

(5). The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism. By identifying this bacterium to be the same as the original, scientists can conclusively assert the causal link between this bacterium and the disease. In such a manner, Koch’s Postulates elucidate the etiology of diseases by linking them to specific microorganisms.

(6). Koch’s Postulates are a helpful tool that allows scientists to approach the causative agent of disease in a logical manner. These postulates have been used as a checklist when designing and implementing experiments to systematically arrive at causal relationships between microorganisms and diseases. For instance, a scientist approaching the etiology of salmonellosis using this paradigm may utilize two specimens- A and B. Specimen B is observed to have diarrhea and fever while no symptoms are observed for A. Diameter of colonies, in millimeters, represents bacterial growth with a greater diameter illustrating more proliferation of the bacterium. Positive control was pure salmonella enterica injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. Negative control was saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C.

Thus, drawing one-to-one relationships between such species and the diseases they cause can prove to be difficult as they deviate from Koch’s Postulates.

(8). Furthermore, many pathogens are unable to grow in nutrient medium culture which appear to violate Koch’s second postulate. These include the Heaemophilus parainfluenzae, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella kingae. Although these pathogens can cause endocarditis in children, they are notoriously known to be difficult to isolate and grow in culture.

(9). It is also important to note that pathogenesis can be a multi-step process. Myocardial infarction for example, is the result of numerous conditions happening in sequence. Although bacterial infection is apart of this sequence, it is not the only thing that causes this disease. Thus, assigning the bacteria as the causative agent is erroneous. Likewise, the discovery of prions- nonliving agents that cause transmissible diseases in healthy individuals, complicates matters as it implies that living organisms do not need to be the cause of a disease. Hence, there are numerous limitations and exceptions when it comes to applying Koch’s Postulates to the study of diseases.

(10). Regardless, the fact remains that Koch’s Postulates transformed the way scientists approached diseases by making them realize that something as small as microorganisms can indeed have large-scale effects.

question.text: A scientist employs several phenotypic and genotypic techniques to accurately identify and match two bacterial isolates. What postulate are they attempting to satisfy?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 5 states: “The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism. By identifying this bacterium to be the same as the original, scientists can conclusively assert the causal link between this bacterium and the disease.” In the question, the scientist is using various techniques to match two bacterial isolates- presumably, the isolates from the originally infected and the inoculated individuals. By observing that both these bacteria match, the scientist can be certain that it is indeed the causative agent of the disease they are investigating. Postulate 4 focuses on isolating the bacterium from the inoculated individual and matching it to the originally infected individual’s bacterium. Thus, the scientist is attempting to satisfy the fourth postulate. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Notably, the healthy individual would NOT have the causative bacterium in the first place. Thus, the scientist in question would not be employing various techniques to compare the bacteria isolates of an infected individual with a healthy one. Option B. Postulate 2 – is incorrect because in paragraph 3 the author writes, “The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” Postulate 2 focuses on growing the causative agent in a pure culture. There is no mention of comparing bacterial isolates. The scientist in question is not attempting to satisfy the second postulate because they are using techniques that match bacterial isolates, NOT techniques that grow a pure culture. Option C. Postulate 3 – is incorrect because in paragraph 4 the author author writes, “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” Postulate 3 focuses on inoculating a new individual with the causative agent and observing its effects. There is no mention of matching bacteria yet. Thus, the scientist in question is not attempting to satisfy this postulate.

question.text: Use the following information to answer questions 43-46. A scientist is studying the etiology of tuberculosis using the Koch Postulates’ paradigm. While experimenting with Individuals A and B, the scientist makes note of several observations. Table 1 depicts some of these observations. CFU/ml represents colony forming units per milliliter and illustrates the proliferation of the bacterium within a petri dish. Table 1: Assessing Presence and Growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis If the table showed Individual B to have 500 CFU/ml of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in its original blood sample, which one of Koch’s Postulates would be violated?

explanation.concept_text: Two individuals- A and B, are being directly compared. Individual A is depicting symptoms of tuberculosis while Individual B is not. Presumable then, Individual B is the healthy individual. Blood sample from individual A shows the growth of the bacterium – Mycobacterium tuberculosis . This microbe is the suspected causative agent of tuberculosis that the scientist is evaluating. Individual B on the other hand, does not have this bacterium in their blood, as would be expected of a healthy individual. The question however, presents a scenario where Individual B does have this bacterium. This violates Postulate 1 because paragraph 2 states: “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” Since the microorganism is found in the healthy individual (B) as well as the infected individual (A), postulate 1 is violated. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option B. Postulate 2 – is incorrect because in paragraph 3 the author writes, “The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” Postulate 2 focuses on growing the causative agent in a pure culture. In the table, the pure culture is mentioned in the third row. The question however, presents a scenario where the second row is changed. When filling out this row, the scientist is still comparing the two individuals and evaluating their diseased state. Row 3 on the other hand, is when they attempt to satisfy the second postulate through obtaining a pure culture. Therefore, since the scientist is still comparing the diseased states of the individuals, they are focusing on the first postulate, NOT the second. Option C. Postulate 3 – is incorrect because in paragraph 4 the author writes, “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” Postulate 3 focuses on inoculating a new individual with the causative agent and observing its effects. The second row however, is comparing the originally infected individual with a healthy individual prior to inoculation. Since there is no mention of inoculation in the question, postulate 3 is not addressed and so, cannot be the postulate that is violated. Option D. Postulate 4 – is incorrect because in paragraph 5 the author writes, “The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism.” Although this postulate does compare two individuals, this happens after inoculation has occurred. The second row however, is comparing the originally infected individual with a healthy individual prior to inoculation. Since the table in the question depicts data before inoculation has occurred, postulate 4 is not addressed and so, cannot be the postulate that is violated.

However, as Koch later discovered, asymptomatic diseases also exist. Thus, despite the presence of the microorganism, infected individuals can appear to be the same as healthy individuals.

(3). The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture. Pure culture means that only one strand of that microorganism is present. Evidently, when a healthy individual’s blood is sampled and a pure culture is attempted to be made, no growth of the suspected bacteria within the culture medium should be observed.

(4). The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual. Presumably, this newly infected individual would be expected to show symptoms that deviate from when it was healthy. However, once again the presence of asymptomatic diseases complicates this interpretation. Regardless, the individual should objectively demonstrate their infected status, which leads to the fourth postulate.

(5). The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism. By identifying this bacterium to be the same as the original, scientists can conclusively assert the causal link between this bacterium and the disease. In such a manner, Koch’s Postulates elucidate the etiology of diseases by linking them to specific microorganisms.

(6). Koch’s Postulates are a helpful tool that allows scientists to approach the causative agent of disease in a logical manner. These postulates have been used as a checklist when designing and implementing experiments to systematically arrive at causal relationships between microorganisms and diseases. For instance, a scientist approaching the etiology of salmonellosis using this paradigm may utilize two specimens- A and B. Specimen B is observed to have diarrhea and fever while no symptoms are observed for A. When the scientist evaluates the blood sample of both these individuals, they discover the presence of salmonella enterica in Specimen B but not in A. To definitively recognize that the disease individual B is experiencing is caused by this bacterium, the scientist will grow this salmonella enterica in pure culture. This culture will then be inoculated into a healthy Specimen C. If Specimen C develops symptoms identical to Specimen B’s, or more importantly, has the same bacterium as Specimen B in its blood, then the scientist can be certain that indeed this bacterium caused the disease. Figure 1 illustrates the results the scientist can obtain which will conclusively demonstrate the causal link between salmonella enterica and salmonellosis.

Figure 1: Effect of Inoculating Specimen C with Pure Culture Obtained from Specimen B. Blood sample obtained from Specimen C was analyzed to determine the growth of salmonella enterica. Diameter of colonies, in millimeters, represents bacterial growth with a greater diameter illustrating more proliferation of the bacterium. Positive control was pure salmonella enterica injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C. Negative control was saline solution injected into a specimen identical to Specimen C.

(7). Nonetheless, there are limitations that exist with Koch’s Postulates’ applications to infectious diseases. As mentioned before, asymptomatic bacteria seem to violate the first postulate. The Bartonella species, for example, can live within the blood of infected individuals without causing disease. Additionally, these species have been found to cause a variety of phenotypically different diseases. Similarly, several infections are absent from the infected individual once symptoms develop. For example, Group A streptococcus infection is thought to cause rheumatic fever. However, once the lesions of rheumatic fever do appear, the infection is long gone. Thus, drawing one-to-one relationships between such species and the diseases they cause can prove to be difficult as they deviate from Koch’s Postulates.

(8). Furthermore, many pathogens are unable to grow in nutrient medium culture which appear to violate Koch’s second postulate. These include the Mollicute bacteria which causes a myriad of diseases in humans. Viruses as well, do not grow in cell-free media. Hence, isolating pathogens from the infected individual and growing it in pure culture may not always be feasible. Additionally, certain infectious organisms grow poorly in blood cultures. These include the Heaemophilus parainfluenzae, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella kingae. Although these pathogens can cause endocarditis in children, they are notoriously known to be difficult to isolate and grow in culture.

(9). It is also important to note that pathogenesis can be a multi-step process. Myocardial infarction for example, is the result of numerous conditions happening in sequence. Although bacterial infection is apart of this sequence, it is not the only thing that causes this disease. Thus, assigning the bacteria as the causative agent is erroneous. Likewise, the discovery of prions- nonliving agents that cause transmissible diseases in healthy individuals, complicates matters as it implies that living organisms do not need to be the cause of a disease. Hence, there are numerous limitations and exceptions when it comes to applying Koch’s Postulates to the study of diseases.

(10). Since, Koch’s Postulates are unable to account for many infectious diseases, other criteria, such as the Bradford Hill criteria, and advancements in DNA sequencing have largely replaced Koch’s Postulates in examining the etiology of infectious diseases. Regardless, the fact remains that Koch’s Postulates transformed the way scientists approached diseases by making them realize that something as small as microorganisms can indeed have large-scale effects.

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 3 states: “The second postulate states that the microorganism must be isolated from the diseased individual and grown in pure culture.” The third row of the table depicts the results of growing Mycobacterium tuberculosis in pure culture after 1 week. Individual A originally had this bacterium in their blood as evidenced by the second row in the table. Observing 0 CFU/ml of this bacterium in the pure culture indicates that there was NO growth of this bacterium. In other words, the scientist was unable to obtain a pure culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from infected Individual A, thus, violating the second postulate. Therefore, Option A is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Postulate 3 – is incorrect because in paragraph 4 the author writes, “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” Postulate 3 focuses on inoculating a new individual with the causative agent and observing its effects. The third row however, depicts the results of growing a pure culture. Since there is no mention of inoculation in the question, postulate 3 is not addressed and so, cannot be the postulate that is violated. Option D. question.text: Use the following information to answer questions 43-46. A scientist is studying the etiology of tuberculosis using the Koch Postulates’ paradigm. While experimenting with Individuals A and B, the scientist makes note of several observations. Table 1 depicts some of these observations. CFU/ml represents colony forming units per milliliter and illustrates the proliferation of the bacterium within a petri dish. Table 1: Assessing Presence and Growth of Mycobacterium tuberculosis The scientist injects Individual D with a sample obtained from Individual A’s blood. If after 1 week, Individual D remains healthy and the Mycobacterium tuberculosis in their blood sample is 0 CFU/ml, which of Koch’s Postulates is violated?

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 4 states: “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” Individual A is the infected individual. If a sample obtained from this individual is injected into Individual D and their blood sample has no traces of the bacterium, it means that they are free of the disease. Such a scenario would violate the third postulate because the inoculation from the infected individual did NOT cause the disease in the injected individual. Additionally, paragraph 5 states: “The final postulate states that the microorganism must be re-isolated from the inoculated individual and matched to the originally isolated organism.” If the inoculated individual remains free of disease, the microorganism CANNOT be re-isolated and matched to the originally isolated organism. As such, the fourth postulate will also be violated. Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Postulate 1 – is incorrect because in paragraph 2 the author writes, “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” This postulate focuses on what happens BEFORE inoculating a healthy individual with the causative agent. Since, the question presents a scenario where a healthy individual is injected with sample from an infected individual, it focuses on what happens AFTER inoculation. Therefore, postulate 1 is not violated because it is not the focus of this scenario. Option B. Either postulates 1 and 2 – is incorrect because in paragraph 2 the author writes, “The first postulate states that the microorganism must be found in the infected individual and not in healthy individuals.” This postulate focuses on what happens BEFORE inoculating a healthy individual with the causative agent. Since, the question presents a scenario where a healthy individual is injected with sample from an infected individual, it focuses on what happens AFTER inoculation. Therefore, postulate 1 is not violated because it is not the focus of this scenario. Similarly, postulate 2 focuses on “…[isolating] the microorganism […] from the diseased individual and [growing it] in pure culture” (Paragraph 3) which occurs BEFORE inoculation. Thus, postulate 2 is not violated because it is not the focus of this scenario. Option C. Both postulates 2 and 3 – incorrect because postulate 2 focuses on “…[isolating] the microorganism […] from the diseased individual and [growing it] in pure culture” (Paragraph 3) which occurs BEFORE inoculation. The question however, presents a scenario where a healthy individual is injected with sample from an infected individual. Thus, it focuses on what happens AFTER inoculation. Thus, postulate 2 is not violated because it is not the focus of this scenario. Postulate 3 on the other hand is violated. Paragraph 4 states: “The third postulate follows from the second as it states that when the cultured microorganism is inoculated into a healthy individual, it causes the disease in this individual.” If a sample obtained from Individual A is injected into Individual D and their blood sample has no traces of the bacterium, it means that they are free of the disease. Thus, such a scenario would violate the third postulate because the inoculation from the infected individual did NOT cause the disease in the injected individual. Although postulate 3 is violated, postulate 2 is not. Therefore, this option is incorrect because it states that BOTH these postulates are violated.

explanation.concept_text: Paragraph 7 states: “Group A streptococcus infection is thought to cause rheumatic fever .” Therefore, Option D is the correct answer.
explanation.poe_text: Option A. Option B. Endocarditis – is incorrect because paragraph 8 states: “Additionally, certain infectious organisms grow poorly in blood cultures.
